scenes.location: WINSTON AND STRAWN LAW FIRM LOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cavernous lobby in a high powered law firm. Marble and glass everywhere. An echo chamber. SUPERIMPOSE - Washington D.C. - October 2004

dialogues.speaker: NEWCASTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...with 21 days to the election, Time Magazine has President Bush and Senator Kerry each with 48%, a statistical dead heat... MARY MAPES sits. Career woman. Spitfire. Can drink and swear with the boys. Owns multiple curling irons. She sit alone. Waiting. KNITTING. Exhausted. Her eyes flit around as the needles loop and stitch the yarn.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Mr. Hibey will see you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richly appointed. A scotch and cigar feel. Attorney DICK HIBEY (50's, bearded) rises as Mary enters.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: Ms. Mapes. I'm Dick Hibey. What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, I think you know. Hibey smiles, gestures for her to sit. Noticing:

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: You knit?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You don't expect a woman like me to knit.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: No. But it's good. Helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean it blunts my radical feminist agenda?

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: Do you have a radical feminist agenda?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You meet a lot of radical knitters? Hibey smiles politely at the joke. Then:

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: Do you have a substance abuse problem?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm working on developing one.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So am I. Hibey's not smiling anymore.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: You came to me, Ms. Mapes. If you're not up for this-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I've been in news for twenty years. I've won two Emmys, I broke Abu Ghraib, I've done jail time for not revealing sources. I have neither a radical feminist agenda nor a substance abuse problem, although right now I'm gonna take a xanax because this is really freaking me out - do you have any water? A beat. Hibey rises and pours Mary a glass of water from pitcher on the side table. Handing it to her.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: You're going to have to be ready for questions like that.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm up for this.  Hibey retakes his seat. Sizing her up.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: There's an interesting reoccurring theme in the stories you cover. People abusing their power.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don't like bullies.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: Tell me about your work. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You want to know if I'm responsible for what happened.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: Aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I did my job, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: I don't have to believe you. What matters is that they believe you. Now tell me about your work. Mary takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm the producer. I find the story, I put the team together, I write and cut the piece. I work at 60 Minutes.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: And what's that like? And as Mary smiles at the thought, we CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cramped and dark. A large screen shows a photograph of NA PRISONERS from ABU GHRAIB. An EDITOR manipulates a computer program, and one man's c is blurred out with a field of squares...  New York City - April 2004 - Six Months Earlier

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They're really gonna run it this time? Mary sits behind the tech along with COLONEL ROGER CHARLE (former military 50's crewcut) and a pregnant DANA ROBERS

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They're going to run it.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Because you said that last week-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They're going to run it, Roger.

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: You want me to paint them out like this? Mary looks up to the screen to see what the tech is doing digitally painting out men's penises image by image. One man's crotch blurred out with a field of squares.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Jesus, no, it looks like his genitals were attacked by mad cubists. Maybe you could just darken the area? The Technician hits a few keys. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, now it just looks like there's a black hole there.

dialogues.speaker: DANA ROBERSON
dialogues.text: From which no light can escape.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: They're really going to run it? Because Sy Hersh has this and he's going to write a story about how we've sat on it for three weeks-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Dana, tell Roger they're going to run it, then hit him with a large blunt object for me, will you? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking her watch) I gotta go grab him, can you finish this? The Colonel nods. Mary rises as we CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MAN IN PROFILE. Seated in a chair on the wings of a stage. Silhouetted by a spotlight. From ONSTAGE:

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He is, among other things, a piss poor speller. That's why the Houston Chronicle put him on the radio instead of a desk. Three years later, he was their news director. Chuckles from the crowd. Our man withdraws a NOTEPAD from his pocket. Jotting something down. His speech maybe? On stage Andrew Heyward - President of CBS News (50's, mustached) addresses the crowd; a sea of tuxedos and gown

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To call his beginnings humble would be generous. A graduate of that most notable of journalism schools, The Sam Houston State Teacher's College, in 1959 he took his first job in the burgeoning medium of television. A year later, when a hurricane hit Galveston, he convinced his cameraman to shoot the radar screen, showing Americans for the first time how a storm worked. He was the first journalist to report that John F. Kennedy had been shot. He described the Zapruder film in detail to a nation that was not allowed to see it. He became the White House Correspondent at 33 years of age and the Chief London Correspondent a year later. He helped bring the horrors of the Vietnam War into American living rooms for the first time. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a Broadcaster Convention in 1974 where President Nixon was scheduled to appear but not take questions, he, of course, asked a question. Nixon, upset, asked "Are you running for something?" My friend politely replied "No, sir, Mr. President. Are you?" Laughter. Mary slips into the back of the room.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He covered the Russians in Afghanistan and the hostages in Iran. And in 1981 he became anchor of the CBS Evening News. He has now anchored a nightly newscast for longer than anyone else in U.S. history. He has dined with kings, angered Presidents, questioned dictators. Not bad for the son of a ditch-digger from Wharton, Texas. In the wings, the Man flips his notepad shut and gets rea

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, I give you my friend, and the reason I have this job, Dan Rather. The Crowd rises in applause as DAN RATHER steps from the wings. Mary smiles. Dan takes the lectern and pulls a pre written speech from his jacket. What was the notepad?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Andrew, for that wonderful introduction. And yes, I will honor your speaking fee. Off the crowd's laugh we CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the ceremony. Dan and Andrew stand with a DRUNK RIC COUPLE during cocktail hour. Dan is in hell. Mary approaches, looking completely out of place in street clo

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hey, Andrew. I need him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not taking him-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You say that, and yet here I am.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (to Mary) You've got him?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Stashed in a hotel two blocks up. They move for the door. Heyward panics, following them:

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: Dan, you're not leaving your own party! I got fifty affiliates and their wives waiting to meet you-- Goddammit, Mary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Dan exit the gala. Among the fountains, Dan pull off his bow-tie like a kid after Sunday School, barely containing his glee. Pretending to be upset.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I was receiving an award, you know.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You don't say.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: For a "Lifetime of Achievement".

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So it's pretty much all downhill from here, then?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Brother, you ain't kidding. (pause; then) We are going to run it, right?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm going to start hurting you people soon, I swear to God-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying, I've already done cut-ins for it. We kill it now, we look like fools.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not that that's stopped us before. (crossing the street) They're worried about the Superbowl-- Andrew thinks the FCC may fine Viacom per station.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: So the CBS News division has to tread softly because of Janet Jackson's left breast?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We're about to go on national television and accuse the U.S. Military of committing atrocities while hip deep in two wars during an election year. (pause) But yes, mostly I think they're worried about the boob thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set up for an INTERVIEW. A TV CREW waits with a GENERAL seated in a chair. Mary and Dan enter.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: General? This is Dan Rather. Dan sits opposite him, pulling the NOTEPAD from his pocke

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: General, thank you for doing this. Let's start from the beginning... ..-And now we see it's FULL OF QUESTIONS for the intervie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SERIES OF QUICK SHOTS - Anonymous hands turning knobs, balancing color bars. Slotting video tapes into machines. We see a MACRO of tapeheads sliding the magnetic tape int place, spooling it through the machine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock on the wall reads 8:00. We hear the familiar 60 MINUTES STOPWATCH. Colonel Charles, Dana, and others sit watching

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: The image of an IRAQI MAN standing on a box WEARING A HOO Electrodes run to his body. OVER THIS:

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Americans did this to an Iraqi prisoner. According to the US Army, the man was told to stand on a box with his head covered with wires attached to his hands. He was told that if he fell off the box, he would be electrocuted. CUT TO Dan, addressing the camera:

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was this picture and dozens of others that prompted an investigation by the U.S. Army. Yesterday, we asked General Mark Kimmitt, deputy director of Coalition Operations in Iraq, what went wrong.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 60 MINUTES
dialogues.text: And finally to Mary, watching her story come out...

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KIMMITT
dialogues.text: Frankly, I think all of us are disappointed at the actions of the few. You know, every day we love our soldiers, but frankly, some days we're not always proud of our soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Abu Ghraib under Saddam Hussein was infamous. For decades, many who were taken here never came out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ice cubes crackle. A piano plays softly. TV over the bar:  10.

dialogues.speaker: NEWCASTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...CBS's bombshell allegations this evening that prisoner abuse occurred at the Abu Ghraib facility... A few feet away, Mary, Colonel Charles, Dana and Dan sit table celebrating. Happily drunk.

dialogues.speaker: DANA ROBERSON
dialogues.text: I remember when you used to say "Courage" at the end of every broadcast. You remember that? (off Dan's nod) Why'd you stop?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They made fun of him.

dialogues.speaker: DANA ROBERSON
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (mock wounded) They did. Me. Can you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Apparently they thought times back then weren't grave enough to warrant such a sign off.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Give us a "Courage", Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I don't think-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Come on, just one. For me? A beat. Dan leans forward. In his best newscaster bariton

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Courage. The others break up laughing. Dan smiles. Raises a toast.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To a hell of a story.  11.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Once they finally ran it. (vaises her glass) F.E.A. Laughter as they clink and drink, as above the TV continu to blare coverage of their story...

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: SUPERIMPOSE - Dallas, Texas. An inviting two story Crafts with a big front porch.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We're sitting here with Mommy. Thank you for being here Mommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's son ROBERT (7) holds a portable video camera. Mary sits across from him as he conducts an interview with her

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Thank you for having me. Robert nods, all business.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Mommy, you were away for a long time again. What were you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I was in New York working on the news.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: And what does that entail? Mary raises an eyebrow at her son's vocabulary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Asking questions. Questions help reporters get to the truth.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Interesting. Are there any questions you shouldn't ask?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No. Never. Why would you say that?  12.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: My friend Louis's Dad says reporters ask too many questions.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'd be curious to know what your friend Louis's Dad thinks we should do with our time instead.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Were you with the men with the cameras?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Interesting. Can I have a new camera?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We'll have to talk to your father about it for Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I'm trying to get to the truth here, Mommy. Answer the question. Mary smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: This interview is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cluttered with papers. A LARGE TELEVISION above her desk. CNN yammering about Abu Ghraib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .Â»..can't deny that Abu Ghraib is an enormous black eye for the Bush Administration just as John Kerry is emerging as a real challenger in the Presidential Election... Mary's husband MARK WROLSTAD appears in the doorway. Nods to the TV coverage.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: Caused a bit of a ruckus, didn't you?  13.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Who me? She clicks on her email. One from Mike Smith. I've been a bad boy. Have some tasty brisket for you. -Mike

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: You wanna go for a walk? Mary stares at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I think I have to work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SERIES OF SHOTS - Furniture being unwrapped. Boxes bein unpacked. An Oriental Rug being spread on the floor. A LINE OF EMMYS being placed one by one on a bookshelf. As the last one is put down by JOSH HOWARD, (late 30's, mustache). Looks around the office. He's made it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh strides down the hall with MARY MURPHY, (30's, brune his right hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: What's she like?

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Good. Fast. She's Rather's gal. (pause) Makes twice as much as either of us.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming in, Mary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary smiles as she enters Josh's office and shakes his ha

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Not at all, I'm excited to get going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPERIMPOSE - June 2004 Josh smiles back and nods to Murphy next to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: As are we. You know Mary Murphy.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Great to see you again. Abu Ghraib was phenomenal. As they all take a seat.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: So no big preamble, we love you, we love what you've done here - let's talk about the new season. What are you thinking? Mary flips open her notebook.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I got something maybe for the election. Houston businessman named Bill White claims he has documents that the Bin Laden family were investors in Arbusto.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Bush's oil company?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Could just be lots of sound and fury, but Vanity Fair's into it too. That whole time period for Bush is funky.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Funky how?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I did some work on it in 2000. You know Ben Barnes?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Old Texas Pol. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Barnes says when he was Speaker of the Texas House in '68, Sid Adger, this big oilman, comes into his office and asks for help getting young George Bush into the National Guard as a pilot. Poppy Bush at this point is a Congressman and Barnes figures he can use all the connections he can get, so he says he called General Rose, who runs the Texas Air National Guard, and gets Bush a slot.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Barnes told you this?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Completely off the record, but he's been dining out on the story for years. Then I talk to Buck Staudt, who was Bush's squadron commander. He starts screaming at me about how Barnes is full of shit, because everybody knows that he's the one who pulled the strings to get Bush into the Guard, not Barnes. Josh laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Politics in Texas. It's the intergalactic capital of shit happens. Anyway while Bush is in the Guard, he meets a guy named James Bath and they become running buddies. After they get out, Bath, with no resume to speak of, becomes chief financial representative for the Bin Laden Family's interests in Texas. Bush starts up Arbusto and Bath writes him a $50,000 check.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Which your guy White claims is Bin Laden money. (off her nod) Okay, run it down. But if we go with it, we have to go early; we can't October surprise them.  16.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: If you're into this, I'd like to bring in some other people.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Who? Mary reaches into her bag and hands them a list...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLONEL CHARLES stands in full dress uniform at the funer of a VETERAN as a flag is laid over a coffin. OVER THIS:

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Colonel Roger Charles, worked Abu Ghraib for us. Naval Academy grad. Two tours in Vietnam, then the Pentagon. When he's not working for us, he's trying to get better armor for combat troops in Iraq.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Who else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY SCOTT lectures a class of journalism students...

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Since Dana's on maternity leave, I'd like Lucy Scott to run point. She's a CBS veteran, journalism professor in Dallas.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: What about this man... Mike Smith?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A posh COCKTAIL PARTY. A long haired shaggy guy stands by huge potted plant, feeding rum-and-cokes to a clearly dru actor. Pad and pen out. This is MIKE SMITH (20's).

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mikey cut his teeth working for Molly Ivins and was a researcher for us on (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: this in 2000. Last I heard, he was working as a stringer for People.com, sneaking into cocktail parties to find out who's sleeping with who...

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: When you say "sport-fucking", do you mean he's, like, putting it to her for fun, or that he's actively attempting to compete at it? There is a TAP on his shoulder. A BURLY SECURITY GUARD.

dialogues.speaker: BURLY SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Sir, we have to ask you to leave.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Listen, I appreciate where you're coming from, you have your job to do, but I am protected by my First Amendment rights, so, you know, respectfully, go fuck yourself. The Security Guard rolls his eyes and looks to his goons.

dialogues.speaker: BURLY SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: The hard way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onlookers scatters as the goons BODILY CARRY a SCREAMING Mike Smith out the front door of the hotel:

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: A free press is all that stands between you roided out motherfuckers and anarchy! At-tic-a! At-tic-a! As they toss him into a FOUNTAIN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to the scene. Mary gives them a smile.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's a crack team. Trust me.  18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small two story building. Mary walks toward the stairca Smith sits on the stairs. Rumpled clothes and hair.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: You really gonna do it this time? Your evil corporate overlords will let you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Good to see you too, Mikey.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I hear Heyward's talking about closing foreign bureaus, moving in more of a bullshit "infotainment" direction.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Where'd you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I'm a researcher, I research.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They won't touch the news division as long as Dan's there.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Dan's not gonna be there forever. They'll figure a way to get the Old Man out of the chair eventually-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You've never even met him.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Doesn't mean his time hasn't come. Why did he get into journalism anyway if he's not gonna do tough stories? Mary looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How you doing, Mikey?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I'm eating ramen three meals a day and stealing cable, I need a job.  19.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Come meet everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of MILITARY FILES spread out across the table. Lucy Scott and Roger Charles, working as Smith and Mary e The former Marine raises an eyebrow at the newcomer.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Oh, good. You brought me a hippie.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: This is Mike Smith, he worked this with me in 2000. He has no social graces whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: It's true.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Your Arbusto tip is for shit. Bin Laden money never got near Bush.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: So what am I doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We found something else. Bush's time in the Guard. There are some... gaps.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: You are looking at George W. Bush's entire Texas Air National Guard file.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: You mean what's left of it, right? (realizing) You're doing a paper trail. The Colonel picks up a file.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: What we have starts here - May 1968, bloodiest month of the conflict. Bush is accepted to the Texas Air National Guard for flight training.  20.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: If you believe Ben Barnes, he got Bush onto the waiting list.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: If there even was a waiting list. Some people say yes, some people say no. That one General... He snaps his fingers, trying to remember.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Belisario Flores? Colonel Charles looks at Smith - not bad.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Former head of the Texas Guard, he said there was a waiting list, over a hundred people on it.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: So Bush jumped the list.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: We have no document showing any kind of waiting list.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Bush says he got in so quickly because they were specifically looking for pilots, which is bullshit with so many pilots rotating back from Vietnam. And that's another thing - training a National Guard pilot from start to finish was a huge rarity.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Because it's not cost effective. Lot of National Guard jocks are former Air Force pilots who want to maintain their flight rating.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Why spend a million bucks training a new pilot when you can just admit a (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: guy the Air Force already taught how to fly? The only thing that makes Bush an attractive candidate for the Guard is who he's connected to.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Either way, he's in. Signed on for a six year commitment. Does his pilot training at Moody and is then assigned to the 111th Fighter Intercept Squadron in Houston. Records show he does really well here, high marks in every rating period until the spring of 1972. Then nothing. No flights, no appearing for duty. Until August 1 when he is suspended in writing for missing a routine physical.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So how does someone go from being a top-notch pilot to not even taking your physical?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Not only that, but he requests and is granted a reassignment to Alabama to work on a friend's Senate campaign.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Wait - he disobeys an order and then they let him transfer?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: It gets better. From May 1972 to May 1973, his record shows no points registered. Points are like hours on a time card in the Guard. It basically means he didn't show up. The Alabama commander has no recollection of him. No eyewitness has ever placed him on base and no paperwork exists to prove he was ever there. Lucy looks from one of them to the other.  A beat. 22.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You're telling me the President of the United States may have gone AWOL from the military for over a year?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: We have no proof of that.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What does the White House say?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: That Bush served honorably and that military records go missing all the time.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: By the way, military records do not go missing all the time. They're the military. They're good at shit. (looking at file) Bush is not heard from in the records again until July 1973 when he shows up for drills. And in September 1973 he requests and is granted an early discharge to attend Harvard Business School.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: He asks to quit nine months early and they let him?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: And he resigned his commission in '74 which is very weird. You're commissioned for life, right? Why resign it? It makes no sense. Mary looks around the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So what are the questions we're looking to answer?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: One - did Bush go into the Guard to avoid going to Vietnam?  23.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Not to be cynical, but who didn't try to get into the Guard to avoid Nam back then?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Me. The military man says it without blinking. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Bush's trainer in the 147th said he wanted to go to Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: (holds up a paper) This is the only document in the official record that deals with it. On the question of desiring overseas transfer, Bush checked "No".

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Bush's trainer says that must have been a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Cause that's a question you get wrong...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Two - why did he skip the physical?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: He didn't have a drug problem, he just liked the way it smelled. Lucy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And Three - if someone did pull strings for him, who? And how the hell do we get them to go on the record?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Barnes (60's), former Lieutenant Governor of Texas, c in a suit. Pours a scotch on the wet bar next to his desk.  24.

dialogues.speaker: NEWCASTER
dialogues.text: ...The latest Zogby poll which has Senator Kerry leading the President by seven points... Barnes on speaker-phone, voice drawls as smooth as the li

dialogues.speaker: BEN BARNES
dialogues.text: Is it that time of year again already? When I have to fend off the advances of a beautiful woman such as yourself?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You got the President into the National Guard, Governor. I find that very impressive.

dialogues.speaker: BEN BARNES
dialogues.text: It is impressive, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why don't you come on TV, tell us all about it?

dialogues.speaker: BEN BARNES
dialogues.text: We both know if I ever said that about Texas's favorite son on camera they'd run me outta Austin on a rail. (looking at the TV) Sorry, Mary. Johnny's gonna win this thing, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary ducks her head in where Mike and Lucy sit.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Barnes is still a no. Who's next? Lucy walks up to a WHITE BOARD with a LIST OF NAMES on it Draws a line through Ben Barnes. Looking to the next one.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Colonel Jerry Killian, Bush's CO in the 111th. If anyone is able to really tell us what went on, he will.  25.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Small problem there.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Which is?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Killian's dead. Lucy looks to Smith, who nods.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: It's a pickle.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Who's next? Lucy lines out Jerry Killian and goes to the next...

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: General Buck Staudt, former CO of Bush's 147th Interceptor Squadron...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General BUCK STAUDT spitting mad as he yells into the pho

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL STAUDT
dialogues.text: George was one of the best fucking pilots I ever had! I resent all you goddamn reporters implying that something fishy was going on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy lines out Buck Staudt and moves onto the next.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: General Bobby Hodges, succeeded Staudt as Commander of the 147th, Killian's direct supervisor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, phone to her ear, hearing:

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He was like all Second Lieutenants, bright eyed and bushy tailed. But no strings were pulled for him.  INT. 26.

dialogues.speaker: DALLAS BUREAU
dialogues.text: Bobby Hodges lined out. Onto the next: INT. INT. INT. INT. EXT. INT. INT.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Maurice Udell, Bush's flight instructor...

dialogues.speaker: MAURICE UDELL
dialogues.text: (into phone) No strings were pulled for him. I thought he'd be a great American and a fighter pilot.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Tom Honeycutt...

dialogues.speaker: TOM HONEYCUTT
dialogues.text: (into phone) No strings were pulled.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Albert Lloyd...

dialogues.speaker: ALBERT LLOYD
dialogues.text: (into phone) No strings were pulled.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Bill Hollowell.

dialogues.speaker: BILL HOLLOWELL
dialogues.text: (into phone) No strings were pulled. And even if they were, it's a non-issue. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BILL HOLLOWELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (honks at another car) Move, you son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPERIMPOSE - August 2004. Every last name on the board h a line through it. Mary sits, staring at the names. Tryin to find a way in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan, getting dressed for a black tie event. Mary talks to him through his speaker-phone, INTERCUT:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's like they were given talking points. He was a great guy and no strings were pulled.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Devil's advocate? What if no strings were pulled?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You know who else was in the 147th? Lloyd Bensten's son, John Connally's son, both Sid Adger's sons, H.L. Hunt's grandson, and the heirs to the Sakowitz fortune. But I'm sure it's just a coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: So what's our next move? Mary shakes her head. Staring at the names.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late. Wrolstad snores lightly. On Mary. Can't sleep. The TV plays. A SWIFT BOAT AD. A montage of older VETERANS speaking to the camera, with a background of military ima

dialogues.speaker: VETERAN 1
dialogues.text: I served with John Kerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I served with John Kerry.

dialogues.speaker: VETERAN 3
dialogues.text: John Kerry has not been honest about what happened in Vietnam.

dialogues.speaker: VETERAN 4
dialogues.text: He is lying about his record.

dialogues.speaker: VETERAN 5
dialogues.text: John Kerry has not been honest...

dialogues.speaker: VETERAN 6
dialogues.text: And he lacks the capacity to lead.

dialogues.speaker: VETERAN 7
dialogues.text: When the chips were down, you could not count on John Kerry.

dialogues.speaker: VETERAN 8
dialogues.text: John Kerry is no war hero- The PHONE RINGS. Wrolstad stirs in the bed next to her.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: My secret lover. Go back to sleep. Wrolstad grunts and rolls over. Mary scoops up the receiv

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You ever hear of Linda Starr? Runs a website, clearing house for anti- Bush stuff. She's hinting documents are going to be floated soon.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What kind of documents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh drinks coffee as an ASSISTANT pokes her head in.  29.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Mary Mapes is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, bleary, handwritten notes in front of her, fixing a bowl of Cheerios for Robert across from her. INTERCUT:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I think we got something. Anti-Bush internet rabble-rouser. I talked to her for three hours, but she put me in touch with her source, a Colonel who says he may have access to missing documents from Bush's purged Guard file. I got Mike Smith talking to him right now. Robert looks at his bowl. Mary INT. Mary cups

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Milk? retrieves a carton of milk from the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Get a look at those documents. And do some background, make sure the Colonel isn't nuts.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN DINER
dialogues.text: sits in a booth across from reporter JIM MOORE. Steaming of coffee in front of both of them.

dialogues.speaker: JIM MOORE
dialogues.text: Colonel Burkett is nuts.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, good.

dialogues.speaker: JIM MOORE
dialogues.text: But he's also on the level.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: JIM MOORE
dialogues.text: He's a whistle-blower. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JIM MOORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And whistle-blowers are consistently unbalanced, angry grudge-holders. That's what makes them want to blow their whistles in the first place. (leaning forward) He claims he was there for the scrubbing.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The scrubbing?

dialogues.speaker: JIM MOORE
dialogues.text: Of Bush's Guard file. 1997, Burkett, George Conn, a couple other people say that a bunch of Bushies went down to the Guard Headquarters in Austin and made certain unfavorable parts of his file disappear. You've seen the official record right? Holes in it big enough to drive a truck through.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So you believe him.

dialogues.speaker: JIM MOORE
dialogues.text: Enough to devote a hundred and twenty pages in my new book to him. He takes a sip of his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: JIM MOORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're going to want to be careful with this. The administration doesn't take kindly to this type of reporting.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I didn't exactly make friends with them on Abu Ghraib-

dialogues.speaker: JIM MOORE
dialogues.text: This is different. You're talking about screwing with the man himself.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The President.  31.

dialogues.speaker: JIM MOORE
dialogues.text: After I did my first book on Bush? My name mysteriously popped up on the terrorist no-fly list. Now, I can't hop a puddle jumper without a strip search. They don't forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary coming home, hears SMITH'S VOICE coming from the kit

dialogues.speaker: SMITH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...Then you gotta know about the 1996 Telcom Act...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith sits across from Robert, who is interviewing him.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: See, the rules were no company could own more than one TV station, radio station, or newspaper in the same market - so no one could have a monopoly on the flow of information. But the '96 Act eliminated the cross ownership ban and now TV News is controlled by only five corporations - GE, Disney, Time Warner, NewsCorp, and Viacom - which owns CBS. And all of these mega-corporations rely on what? Robert just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I'm seven.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: On corporate tax breaks and favorable government legislation! That means the government controls the financial well-being of the very institutions that are supposed to report on them! At best it's collusion. Can you still report the news? Sure. As long as it doesn't get in the way of the golden rule - thou shalt always protect the company.  32.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ever think maybe you're just paranoid? Smith turns to see her standing there. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Once. But I dismissed it as paranoia. (vising) We have a problem. Burkett's talking to other outlets. New York Times, Vanity Fair-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You gotta get him to meet with us and bring the documents.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: He does that, he loses all his bargaining power. He wants money.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: He's worried he's going to have to relocate after this. He's worried this will put him in danger. Shit, he's worried his phone is tapped.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Mary, if these really are missing pieces of a sitting President's military record, we are talking about the Holy Grail of documents. If we won't pay, someone else will. The clock ticks. Mary, slowly:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Tell Burkett we don't believe him.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: But we do believe him.  33.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Tell him if he wants to keep us on the hook, he's going to have to show us something to prove his story. Smith stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You get me in a room with those documents, and I will close him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deep Texas. A burger chain. The sign blares WHATABURGER! SUPERIMPOSE - September 2004. Mary and Smith pull to a ha in front of the bright orange restaurant. After a bit:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You figure they really have to have confidence in their burgers to name a restaurant that. Smith nods. Then:

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: How early are we? A beat. They exchange a glance, thinking the same thing..

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT TO
dialogues.text: Mary and Smith, now EATING BURGERS. Smith, mouth full:

dialogues.speaker: SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are really good. Mary nods. Scanning the people outside.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What do they look like?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: The Burketts? I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Then how do we recognize them?  34.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I don't know, I thought you Googled them or something.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We've arranged a clandestine Whataburger rendezvous with a man who wants to bring down the President of the United States and we don't even know what he looks like? A RAPPING on Mary's window and she turns to see a very TA OLDER WOMAN standing there. Behind her is a taller gaunt older man. COLONEL BILL BURKETT. Looks around, suspicious

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: Y'all stay in the car. In case someone listened to our calls, we're gonna go to a secondary location. Mary gives Smith a look as Burkett heads back to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foursome occupy a BOOTH. Colorful kids' placemats in front of them. A birthday party in the background. Nicki helps Burkett take sucks off an oxygen mask, as a WAITRES delivers four huge sodas to the table. When she's gone--

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: I saw it with my own eyes. They put the parts of Bush's file they didn't like in a wastebasket.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And do you have these documents?

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: Bill tried to talk about this in 2000 and someone ran us off the road one night.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: I ain't scared of them-

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: Well, I am. I am scared. She takes a deep gulp of iced tea. Nerves shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's say I have the documents. Why should we show 'em to you? Why not one of the newspapers-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Because nobody reads newspapers. Burkett blinks.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: One of the other networks then-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don't know if you've noticed, but not many people actually do what we do anymore. (pause) We're 60 Minutes. We're the gold standard. And we can help you. Look, you come on camera and we'll-

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: No. No cameras. Our name stays out of this. (to Burkett) They will destroy us for this. Don't you understand? She looks at her husband, pleading. Mary stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Nicki, listen. I know what it's like to be bullied. To feel like they're too strong, that you're small and powerless. But you are not. And doing this will show them that. (pause) I promise. We will protect you. 35. A beat. Nicki and Burkett exchange a glance. Like a weigh has shifted at the table. And then very slowly, Burkett pulls out a photocopied piece of paper. The top reads 111th Fighter Interceptor Squadron And the date 01 August 1972  36. Mary's eyes flit over different words and phrases - ist Lt. Bush be suspended from flight status due to failu to perform to USAF/TexANG standards... ...No attempt to meet his training certification or fligh physical... ...Desire to transfer out of state including assignment t non-flying billets... Mary looks up at Burkett.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is signed by Jerry Killian. Burkett hands them a second document.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: This too. First one says Bush made no attempt to meet his training certification - that's a big difference than just missing his physical. Second one refers to his pilot position as "critical".

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Bush said he stopped flying because he was no longer needed as a pilot...

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: This document would prove that statement untrue.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Can you think of anyone who would want to fool you with these? Like a political dirty trick? Burkett blinks. The thought never occurred to him.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: I can't believe someone would hate me that much.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Do you have the originals?  37.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: No, I was only given copies. And don't ask me where, I'm not telling you anything else. You get some experts of your own to look at them. Mary nods as Smith signals for the check.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decked out with POLITICAL TRAPPINGS. Various reporters, looking down at the speech occurring on the floor. Ona NEWSCASTER doing a stand up:

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: ...-Believe The Swift Boat ads coupled with a usual post-Convention bump could give the President as much as a ten point lead over Senator Kerry... SUPERIMPOSE - Republican National Convention IN THE CBS BOOTH - Dan Rather holds a cell phone to his e

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I said, we've got âem!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, driving, while scanning the documents. INTERCUT:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They contradict Bush's official story, the one he put in his autobiography, the one he ran on-

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Mary, could you not read, drive, and talk on the phone at the same time?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I got Lucy pulling together document examiners, but we need to start getting people on camera. What's your schedule after the convention?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurricane Frances is supposed to make landfall Friday-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, no, no-

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You know how I feel about hurricanes, Mary. They are incredible displays of nature's power-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They're wind. I am asking you as a friend, please do not go to this hurricane- The car POPS A CURB.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Mary! Mary pulls over.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm going to start talking to Josh about timing.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Good. I knew you could do this, Mary. Mary smiles. He hangs up. Breaks the connection. Mary stows her cell phone and restarts the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Back there, what you said to Nicki Burkett about being bullied?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: That was good. It didn't sound like you just trying to close her. It sounded real.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Good.  39. She puts the car in gear and drives...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan stows his phone. On the convention floor GOVERNOR GEO PATAKI is wrapping up the keynote address.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE PATAKI
dialogues.text: ...-He is one of those men God and fate somehow lead to the fore in times of challenge. And he is lighting the way to better times, a safer land, and hope. (pause) He is my friend, he is our President, President George W. Bush! The crowd explodes in applause as PRESIDENT BUSH makes hi way to the podium. High in the CBS Booth, Dan Rather watc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary walks up her driveway, dodging Robert's toys, balanc a cup of Starbucks and her phone to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Our premiere is September 29th but the story won't hold till then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh, looks up at his SCHEDULE BOARD - the CBS schedule f the next two months. Mary Murphy with him. INTERCUT:

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: September 15th we don't have a show - CBS is running the Billy Graham crusade.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What about the 22nd?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Preempted again. Dr. Phil special.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So our airdate is being decided by an unholy confluence of Billy Graham and Dr. Phil McGraw?  40.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: News doesn't pay the bills.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: There is one more option. The 8th. Mary takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: As in five days from now?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: If it can't be done-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'd need interviews, I'd need to get my whole team to New York, I'd need-- First, I need Dan. Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ON TELEVISION - Dan, screaming into a mic as he is POUNDE by WIND AND RAIN.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Hurricane Frances is pounding Florida harder than a strong man at a state fair trying to win a kewpie doll!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, watching as the wind almost blows him over.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm gonna kill him. As ONSCREEN DAN is almost taken out by a flying tree bran

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: You may not have to. (checking his laptop) I can maybe get him on a puddle jumper to Austin for the Strong interview. Got an email from the Colonel about the documents saying "I feel better". She scans the email and grabs the phone...  41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Colonel scoops up his ringing phone.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: A memorandum for record is a memo to nobody, right? So why does Killian file them?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Killian knows suspending a guy this protected is a big deal. He's trying to do the right thing here, but wants a paper trail to insulate himself.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Which means W's protection must have come from higher up than Killian.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: You're thinking Hodges, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He was Killian's direct supervisor... I'll call you back. Mary hangs up. Checks her notes for another number - Gen. Bobby Hodges. Dials. Rings. ANSWERING MACHINE:

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You have reached Robert Hodges, please leave a message.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: General Hodges, this is Mary Mapes from 60 Minutes; I was hoping you could give me a call back at your earliest convenience-

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: You gotta see this! He hands her his laptop. Onscreen, shaky CELL PHONE VIDEO  42.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cell phone video from a Democratic fund raiser. A MAN is addressing a CROWD. Mary squints at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is that Ben Barnes?

dialogues.speaker: BEN BARNES
dialogues.text: Let's talk a minute about John Kerry and George Bush, and I know them both. And I'm not name dropping. See I... I got a young man named George Bush into the National Guard when I was the Lt. Governor of Texas. I'm not necessarily proud of that...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnes, on the phone with Mary, clearly distressed:

dialogues.speaker: BEN BARNES
dialogues.text: I didn't know they were taping me! Did you see it? I looked like shit!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (smiling) I thought you looked wonderful, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BEN BARNES
dialogues.text: Oh, don't you start.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The cat's already out of the bag and your man Kerry is almost ten points down. We're airing our piece in four days. Are you in or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith, pulling on his jacket. From the other room:

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We got Barnes!  43.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Burkett just called, he's got more memos he wants to hand off. He moves for the door as Mary comes in.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We need to find out who his source is. I have to be at the airport in the morning-

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I'll fax you what I get! And he's out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, dressed in travel clothes. Standing with Wrolstad i the door of Robert's room, looking at their sleeping son.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He's gotten so big.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: (nods ) It's a problem. Mary goes and leans down next to Robert's bed and kisses on the cheek. He stirs.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I gotta go, kiddo. Big story, gotta go ask questions.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (yawning) With the men with the cameras?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (smiles at the question) Yes, with the men with the cameras. He rolls over. She kisses him again and rises. Goes to th door where Wrolstad stands. He whispers to her:

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: You be careful, okay? This is honor and duty. This is where they live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'll be careful, Mark. Wrolstad nods. Enough for him. She kisses him and starts for the stairs. Turns back, with a thought.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe you should let him watch this one. Wrolstad nods. Okay. She kisses him once more and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: September 5th - 3 Days To Air. An amazingly disheveled Da Rather comes down the jetway. Mary holds up a folder.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: More memos from Burkett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Dan sit in a bank of chairs as travelers swirl a them. Dan, scanning the new memos. He stops, reading alou

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: "Staudt has obviously pressured Hodges more about Bush. I'm having trouble running interference and doing my job. Harris gave me a message today from Group regarding Bush's OETR... He looks at Mary, questioning.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Officer Effectiveness Training Report.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: "Staudt is pushing to sugar coat it. Bush wasn't here during rating period and I don't have any feedback from 187th in Alabama. I will not rate." (pause) Bush wasn't here during rating period...  45.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They're trying to get Killian to file a rating for Bush while he wasn't even on base. (pause) This is proof that he was AWOL. A long beat. Dan looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Who am I talking to first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert Strong - Former Texas Air National Guard (60's) sits in a chair. Dan across from him. CAMERA ROLLING.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Is there any doubt in your mind that these memos are genuine?

dialogues.speaker: STRONG
dialogues.text: Well, they are compatible with the way business was done at that time. They are compatible with the man that I remember Jerry Killian being. Off to the side, Mary, Lucy, and Smith stand watching.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: What do you think Colonel Killian was trying to do with these memos?

dialogues.speaker: STRONG
dialogues.text: I think he was trying to get a duty performed and I think he was trying to protect himself because of the political environment in which he found himself.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Political considerations were a major force in the Guard?

dialogues.speaker: STRONG
dialogues.text: It verged on outright corruption the favors that were done, the power that was traded. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: STRONG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: From a moral and ethical standpoint, it was unconscionable.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT TO
dialogues.text: After the interview. The cameraman is packing up as Dan bids farewell to Robert Strong. Mary looks to the others.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Let's go to New York...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A night flight. Most people doze in the dark cabin. Smith reads. Someone takes a seat next to him. He looks up to see it is Dan Rather.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I didn't get the chance to introduce myself before. Dan Rather.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: (star-struck) No shit. I mean, Mike Smith. I mean- yes. You are. I'm Mike. Smith. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Mary says you're the one who calls me "The Old Man"?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I- wow. Really not happy she shared that with you. Dan smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I want to thank you for all your hard work on this. It's important. Questioning things. People say it doesn't matter, one side or the other will always say we're being partisan... but the day we stop asking questions is the day the American people lose. It may sound hokey, but I really believe that.  47. ELSEWHERE ON THE PLANE - Lucy and Colonel Charles sit nex to each other, going through documents.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You know what's crazy?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Many things are crazy. Tell me what specifically you feel is crazy.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: The fact they kept this secret for so long. Colonel Charles looks over to Mary dozing a few seats awa

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: You know why Mary didn't get this story done in 2000, don't you? Lucy shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Her mother died. Right in the middle of it. So this story never got finished and the election happened. An election decided by 537 votes. (pause) Sometimes I think if Mary's mom hadn't died that summer, there's a good chance Al Gore would be President right now.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What about her father?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Mary's father is a drunken piece of shit who hated himself so much that he beat his daughters. The more outspoken they were, the harder he hit them. How do you think she fared? Lucy looks at Mary's sleeping form.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: She'd get beat up for asking questions?  48.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: And this is what she does for a living. Dan retakes his seat next to a sleeping Mary as the Colon and Lucy watch.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: People are funny sometimes. That's part of what it is between her and Dan, I think. Why they work so well together. Why they need each other. (shakes his head) Fathers and daughters. Lucy doesn't know how to respond. Pan to Mary. The plane flies on through the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: September 6th - 2 Days To Air. The lobby of 555 West 57th Our team strides across it bleary eyed.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Tell me about the document examiners.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: There are four. We have Marcel Matley coming in from San Francisco today to do on-camera. Linda James in Texas wants to see the originals-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So would I, but we don't have them.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: That's what I told her. Jim Pierce in Los Angeles just got started today and Emily Will in North Carolina wants you to call her... As they step into the elevators

dialogues.speaker: EMILY WILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I think you have a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sits at her desk unpacking her carry-on, on the phon with Emily Will - Document Examiner. INTERCUT:

dialogues.speaker: EMILY WILL
dialogues.text: I've been doing some internet research. The President was in Alabama when these were written, so there's no way they could be true.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Have you found anything wrong with the documents themselves?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY WILL
dialogues.text: No, but-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do they appear forged in any way?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY WILL
dialogues.text: Without the originals to ink test-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Let me worry about the investigational side of the story.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY WILL
dialogues.text: I always work the whole thing. (pause) Do you know where these originated? Establishing exact chain of custody would go a long way towards determining authenticity.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We're working on it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burkett, on the phone with Mary. INTERCUT:

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: I give you the memos, you verify them, that was the deal. You call the Kerry campaign for me yet? They can't lie down on this swift boat shit.  50.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: If I could just confirm where you got the memos, we would be home free.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: I told you, I can't go on the record-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You wouldn't have to. Just give me the name. That's all I need. A beat. Burkett exhaling. Then:

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: George Conn. Buddy of mine in the Guard. He was there for the scrubbing. But you call him and he'll deny it.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT TO
dialogues.text: Through Mary's phone:

dialogues.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You've reached the Conn Residence, please leave a message at the beep.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Colonel, this is Mary Mapes, I'ma producer at 60 Minutes. If you could call me back at your earliest convenience, it's regarding a story we're airing Wednesday night. She hangs up as Colonel Charles pokes his head in.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Matley's ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now set up for an interview. Several ENLARGEMENTS of signatures hang on a board. Marcel Matley - Document Exam stands taking Dan through them as the CAMERA ROLLS.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL MATLEY
dialogues.text: I would say based on our available handwriting evidence, yes, this is the same person. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL MATLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, this signature on the June 24th document shows some conspicuous differences, but it also shows what I call inconspicuous similarities to Colonel Killian's handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Why might differences like that exist?

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL MATLEY
dialogues.text: The content of the memo is highly stressful, Killian telling a higher up that he cannot rate Bush during his absence. This is enough to explain differences in the penstrokes. Dan just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Would you give us a moment? He turns and walks over to where Mary stands.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's like listening to someone describing paint dry-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He said it, though. It was in there somewhere. Can you get the bite? Dan nods and walks back to Matley.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Are you saying that if I present these to the American public and say, to the best of our knowledge, these documents were all signed by the same man, I am going to be on solid ground? A beat. Everyone leans forward to hear. On Matley.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL MATLEY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the interview. Matley has departed, the equipment sits dormant. Dan stands with Mary, Lucy, and Colonel Charles.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Matley's a yes, Jim Pierce is a yes, Emily Will's still working and Linda James wants more documents, but says she'll defer to Matley.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: All the dates and content in the Burkett memos mesh perfectly with the official record - I'm trying to have graphics mock something up to show it visually. They look to Dan. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: We don't have it yet. Groans from the others. Dan presses forward.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Someone has to confirm the content of the memos. Someone who knew the players.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: No one from the Guard is gonna step up for that. Look at what happened to Burkett - you talk, you get your head chopped off.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: What about Killian's family?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Super Pro-Bush so they'd never go for it, plus there was a divorce there. I don't know if she'd know anything.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Who were Killian's commanders again?  53.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Buck Staudt, who has figuratively and literally told me to go fuck myself, and Bobby Hodges, who I've left eighteen messages for. Dan stares at her. His meaning clear.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fine, I'll go do nineteen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith lies on the couch. Colonel Charles tosses a ball ba and forth between his hands nervously. Mary dials her pho

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: You want to get pizza? (to Colonel Charles) We should get pizza. The phone is ringing. Picked up. Through the receiver:

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello? Mary blinks, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: General Hodges?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes. Mary snaps her fingers for them to pick up a second line listen in.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: This is, uh, Mary Mapes with 60 Minutes? I'd like to speak with you about some old memos I've come across from the 111th Fighter Interceptor Squadron. They appear to be from the personal files of Jerry Killian? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay.  54.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'd like to read them to you if that's all right?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Um, the first one is dated June 24, 1973 and the Subject is Bush, George W, ist Lieutenant. (reading) Sir: I got a call from your staff concerning the evaluation of Ist Lieutenant Bush due this month. His rater is Lieutenant Colonel Harris. Neither Lieutenant Colonel Harris or I feel we can rate lst Lieutenant Bush since he was not training with the 111th FIS since April 1972. His recent activity is outside the rating period. Advise me how we are supposed to handle this. Hodges says nothing. Just breathes. Smith and Colonel Charles are both staring, in disbelief Hodges hasn't hung up. Mary fumbles for a second memo.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, this one is August 18, 1973 and titled Subject: CYA, which I believe means "Cover Your Ass"? (reading) Staudt has obviously pressured Hodges more about Bush. I'm having trouble running interference and doing my job. No response. She continues.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Harris gave me a message today from Group regarding Bush's OETR. And Staudt is pushing to sugar coat it. Bush wasn't here during rating period and I don't have any feedback from 187th in Alabama. I will not rate. Austin is not happy either. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. 55.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Harris took the call from Group today. I will backdate but won't rate. Harris agrees. You could hear a pin drop. Mary lowers the paper.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir, are these memos familiar to you? A short exhale of breath from Hodges. Then:

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They are. Smith pumps his fist in victory!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Using someone's personal notes, that's going overboard. You're trying to make news, create a story here when there isn't one.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We're not trying to create anything, General. Colonel Killian was upset Bush missed his physical?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He was an overboard hardnose. He didn't like the weekend guys. But Bush went to Alabama with everyone's blessing. Killian thought he was doing the best job he could. You're creating a situation here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan looks up to see Mary standing in his doorway, beaming Dan grins.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We have it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 60 MINUTES
dialogues.text: Close on Dan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me the truth, the whole truth about what happened with George W. Bush and the draft and the National Guard. Sitting across from him, BEN BARNES heaves a sigh. looks on, along with JOSH HOWARD and MARY MURPHY. September 7th - 1 Day To Air

dialogues.speaker: BEN BARNES
dialogues.text: (deep breath) Sid Adger, a friend of the Bush family, came to see me and asked me if I would recommend George W. Bush for the Air National Guard. And I did.
Mary Mary, Colonel Charles, Smith, Lucy, Mary Murphy, and Josh are crowded into the office.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm concerned about the sheer amount of story we have. Barnes, the documents, missing the physical, being AWOL from Alabama--

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: It's like four different angles on the same story.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Maybe we could split them? Run Barnes tomorrow and the documents on the Sunday broadcast?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Sunday show won't give us the real estate. Where are we with the rest of it? Lucy checks her notes.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Got an email from Emily Will, one of the examiners. She has some concerns about the superscript thing.  57.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Superscript?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: The raised "th" that comes after "111th". She was worried that function wasn't available on military typewriters in the 70's. (to Lucy) I spoke to Matley - he says they were available then. Emily told me she deferred to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Good. White House will have someone for on camera in the morning. I can't send Dan because of the storm.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That fucking hurricane hates me.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 60 MINUTES
dialogues.text: September 8th - Day Of Air. Dark. The whole team sits, screening a ROUGH CUT of their piece on a drop down scree Mary, Smith, Colonel Charles, Lucy, Josh, and Mary Murphy There are lawyers and executives watching as well. ON THE SCREEN - Dan speaking with Barnes:

dialogues.speaker: BEN BARNES
dialogues.text: I don't think I had any right to have the power that I had, to choose who was going to go to Vietnam and who was not going to go to Vietnam. That's power. In some instances, when I looked at those names, I was maybe determining life or death. And that's not a power that I want to have.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Too strong or not to say that you are ashamed of it now?

dialogues.speaker: BEN BARNES
dialogues.text: Oh, I think that would be somewhat of an appropriate thing. I'm very, very sorry.  58. Cut to the 60 MINUTES STOPWATCH - Tick, tick, tick, tick. The lights come up. The first person to speak is Betsy We Senior Vice President, Prime Time.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: What's it running?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Sixteen minutes, at least three over.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Some of the document stuff is slow, you can definitely trim there.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: How about flipping it - open with Barnes and then do the documents. It would keep it chronological. Betsy's nodding, she likes the idea.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: You've got three hours. Pan to the wall where the clock reads 4:10...

dialogues.speaker: INT. 60 MINUTES
dialogues.text: The clock on the wall here reads 6:52. An EDITOR toggles the footage back and forth. ONSCREEN:

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL MATLEY
dialogues.text: .--Based on our available handwriting evidence, yes, this is the same person. Now, this signature on the June 24th document shows some conspicuous differences, but it also shows what I call inconspicuous similarities... Josh taps our Mary on the shoulder and motions her out in the hall. She follows. Hushed:

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: We need to lose Matley. We're forty seconds over and he's a shit interview. The meshing graphic's terrible too.  59.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It shows where the new documents fall in line with the originals-

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Poorly. We're out of time. It's your call. What do you want to do? On Mary. A long beat...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Cut it.

dialogues.speaker: TIMECUT TO
dialogues.text: Clock - 7:44. Everyone tense. The closest they've ever cu it. Mary stares at the screen. The others stare at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: We have to start outputting in two minutes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: We don't start outputting in two minutes, we will not have a show. Sweat on her brow. Stares at the screen. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Lock it. Start outputting. She pushes back from the controls as the techs swoop in a start pushing buttons, outputting the report to tape. The Editor glances at the clock.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: If there's a computer hiccup...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Tom, I worship you, but shut the fuck up. All eyes on the progress bar. 20%... 30%... 40%...

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: This is really tense.  60. Nobody responds. Finally the computer PINGS with a done sound. Mary ejects the tape and hands it to Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Go! Lucy RUNS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrolstad sits with Robert. Clock on the wall, 8:00. Strai up. From their TV - tick, tick, tick, tick, tick...

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: Dan sits in front of an image the reads "FOR THE RECORD"

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: The military records of the two men running for president have become part of the political arsenal in this campaign - a tool for building up, or blowing up, each candidate's credibility as America's next commander-in-chief. Robert looks up at the TV, toys momentarily forgotten...

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: While Senator Kerry has been targeted for what he did in Vietnam, President Bush has been criticized for avoiding Vietnam by landing a spot in the Texas Air National Guard - and then apparently failing to meet some of his obligations in the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burkett and Nicki, together on their couch...

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Did then Lieutenant Bush fulfill all of his military obligations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnes sits alone with a glass of scotch, not watching...  61.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And just how did he land that spot in the National Guard in the first place?

dialogues.speaker: INT. 60 MINUTES
dialogues.text: Mary, with her team. Push in on her face slowly, taking i the report, finally going out over the air:

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Tonight we have new documents and new information on the President's military service, and the first-ever interview with the man who says he pulled strings to get young George W. Bush into the Texas Air National Guard... Mary smiles. We FADE TO a MONTAGE of different people watching all over the country--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KITCHEN WORKERS and PATRONS eating dinner, watching the T bolted to the wall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRAVELERS waiting for their flights, watching as the stor plays...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOCALS sitting on barstools watching the TV among the christmas lights. People from all different walks of life, all being touche by the power of television.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO
dialogues.text: A MONTAGE of NEWSCASTS - all covering the story. Overlapp soundbites about Bush's Guard service, growing until we s a TELEVISION SET - Showing a Local New York NEWSCAST:

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: ...The 60 Minutes report which unearthed new documents regarding (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL NEWSCASTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: the President is sending shockwaves throughout Washington tonight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Our group, celebrating at the bar. Smith and Lucy watching the TV. The Colonel next to him.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: This is what our business is now. Reporting on reporting. Why break news when you can just talk about other news? Thirty minutes from now, someone's gonna do a story on this guy doing a story on us. And then they'll all win Peabodies.
