dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: This one mattered. Smith smiles at her. Elsewhere Mary's phone rings. She steps away from the group, answering.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: Nice. Even the kid liked it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: You're a hell of a reporter, babe. Mary smiles. Means the world to her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'll be home tomorrow, okay?

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: Okay. Wrolstad hangs up. Mary pockets her phone, turning back t the bar. Then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stands Dan. Talking to some people he knows. He catches her eye. Raises a glass to her. A dignified salute. A beat. She raises hers back. No words spoken. No words needed. A real moment between them. Dan smiles and returns to his conversation. And Mar goes back to her team at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: As we hear more and more reports about the story, now in different languages as it is picked up all over the world

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary crossing the street, headed for building 555...

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...-Latest overnight polls which have Bush's numbers stabilizing and Kerry rising...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, drinking coffee. Checking email. One from Josh. I was just sitting here thinking about how amazing you ar I'm buckled in, waiting to see where you take us next. Le go! Josh Mary smiles. Sips her coffee. A moment of serenity and peace. And then Betsy West comes around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Mary, what's going on? These blogs are saying the memos can be recreated exactly in Microsoft Word. Mary blinks.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Who's saying this?

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: A conservative website. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BETSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (veading a printout) Every one of these memos to file is in a proportionally spaced font, probably Palatino or Times New Roman. As she continues reading, Mary swivels back to her comput opens MS Word, grabs a memo and begins to RETYPE IT...

dialogues.speaker: BETSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In 1972 typewriters used monospaced fonts. The use of proportionally spaced fonts did not come into common use until the introduction of personal computers. They were not widespread until the mid to late 90's. Before then, you needed typesetting equipment, and that wasn't used for personal memos to file. I am saying these documents are forgeries, run through a copier for 15 generations to make them look old. She stops as Mary holds a copy of the memo up to the scre Staring at them both. They look nearly IDENTICAL.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mary... what the hell is going on? Mary stares at the screen. She has no idea.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's on Drudge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh and Mary Murphy, looking at the Drudge Report websit The headline - BUSH DOCUMENTS FAKE.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (reading) The spacing is not just similar, it is identical. Notice that the date lines up perfectly, all the line breaks are in the same places, and all letters line up with the same letters above and below. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JOSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I did not change a single thing from Word's defaults; margins, type size, tab stops, etcetera, are all using the default settings- Josh's phone rings. He stops. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: What the hell are we gonna do? Josh answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Hello? (listens; to Murphy) Betsy's office, right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, Smith, Colonel Charles, and Lucy sit on a couch. Jo and Murphy across from them. Betsy stands with Gil Schwar CBS Public Relations.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWARTZ
dialogues.text: Due respect, did you fuck up?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We had four document examiners working separately and not one of them said the memos weren't real.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWARTZ
dialogues.text: Did any of them try typing them into Microsoft Word?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don't know, Gil, I'm not a document examiner, but I'm assuming part of their job was making sure these things weren't whipped up last Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Just because some guys on the internet have a problem with our reporting-

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: It's not just guys on the internet. ABC News is going after this. Nightline specifically-  66.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You mean they're going after Dan. A beat. Schwartz looks to Betsy.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWARTZ
dialogues.text: Tell them about the superscript.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: It's the little "th" that pops up after you type a number like 111th-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I know what it is, what about it?

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Bloggers are saying it's a big red flag this was done on a computer. They say it didn't exist on typewriters in the 1970's.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: One of our examiners raised that concern as well. Mary shoots her a glance.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Emily Will, yeah, but Matley said they did have them and she deferred to him.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWARTZ
dialogues.text: They will kill us on that. They will kill us on that alone.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I don't understand, what do they want?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They want us to say we're wrong. Because if we're wrong, all the questions we asked about the President's service go away. They're all looking at her now.  67.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, we have the document examiners. We have Bob Strong, who worked at Guard headquarters and says the memos are written in the vernacular of the Guard at the time. And we have Bobby Hodges, Killian's commanding officer, who confirmed both the content of the memos and that they reflected Killian's state of mind at the time. We have this story.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Make sure. Reconfirm with everybody.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWARTZ
dialogues.text: And find us another goddamn "th" in the official record, okay? I wanna ram it down their throats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan, getting made up for the news. Mary pokes her head in

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You've heard?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Yes. And it's bullshit, pardon my French. People have been attacking me for thirty years, it's not going to start bothering me now. Are you okay? Mary nods. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We're gonna be in a fight here, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I still got a few good ones left in me.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You get your contract sewn up yet?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I got the President of the news division his job here, I'll be fine. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now give me something to hit back with.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 60 MINUTES
dialogues.text: STACKS of boxes on the center table. All of them labeled BUSH GUARD RECORDS. Smith, Colonel Charles, and Lucy stan

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: We need to find that "th"... He pulls off the top of the first box...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh, at his desk. ON TV - Dan giving the news:

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: --Killing 9 people and wounding 180. Jemaah Islamiyah, the Southeast Asian terrorist group claimed responsibility-- Josh changes the channel to ABC WORLD NEWS TONIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: PETER JENNINGS
dialogues.text: --Several document experts contacted by ABC News have raised serious questions about the authenticity of these new memos...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, dialing her phone. ABC also on her TV:

dialogues.speaker: PETER JENNINGS
dialogues.text: And then there's this, the little superscript "th". That's something very few typewriters could do in
Mary MUTES Jennings as the phone rings. Through the line:

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You have reached Robert Hodges, please leave a message.  69.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: General Hodges, this is Mary Mapes, we need to get in touch again as soon as possible. Please call me. She hangs up. Rises and goes out her door to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking past the desks, she notices she's drawing the sta of a few co-workers. She's the woman who did this. She heads to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her team still goes through documents. Smith sees her com in. Shakes his head. Mary pulls up a chair to help...

dialogues.speaker: TIMECUT TO
dialogues.text: LATER. The group continues to sift through papers. ON TV NIGHTLINE. A woman being interviewed, the graphic reads Marjorie Connell - Jerry Killian's Widow

dialogues.speaker: MARJORIE CONNELL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Number one, he would not have typed because he did not type. Number two, the wording is very suspect to me. I just can't believe that this is my late husband's words- MUTED. They look up. Josh, holding the remote. Pissed.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Staudt was already out of the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (holding it up) The CYA memo dated August 18, 1973 - "Staudt has obviously pressured Hodges more about Bush." Staudt left the guard in 1972. So how the fuck could he still be pressuring? A beat.  70.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Listen. When a commanding officer-

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: The bloggers are having a field day with this!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: When a General leaves his posting and goes to work for Conoco on the same base he still wields an enormous amount of influence there. Doesn't matter when he left. Back me up, Roger.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: She's right. Josh stares at them.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Forgive me if I don't think everyone's going to see it the way you do. Silence as this sinks in. On TV Gary Killian - Son of Jer Killian is speaking. Almost to make a point, Josh UNMUTES

dialogues.speaker: GARY KILLIAN
dialogues.text: -It was not the nature of my father to keep private files like this, nor would it have been in his own interest to do so. Josh throws the remote on the table and stalks out. A bea

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: This is bad...

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: No. When they start asking to talk to our source? Then it will be bad.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: They're coming for us, Roger. Silence. The Colonel looks back down to his stack of pape and stops.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: I got one.  71. Everyone looks it him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: (staring at the page) I... have a superscript "th". Here. And they're moving towards him now, taking the paper from him. Looking to see, a superscript "th", plain as day.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Josh! Josh rushes back in. Mary holds up the page for him to se

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Call Dan, tell him we just got in the fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun shining as it rises...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan sits at his kitchen table. Drinking his coffee watchi

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE STEPHANOPOLOUS
dialogues.text: CBS is still standing by its story and in fact they're also pointing to another source, a Colonel Robert Hodges, who was an immediate superior to Mr. Killian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary typing feverishly. Her TV plays the same broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE STEPHANOPOLOUS
dialogues.text: They said they read these documents to Colonel Hodges and he said "that sounds like what Killian was telling me at the time". Hodges is not speaking to anyone else yet.  72.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (shouting at the TV) Because we can't get him on the fucking phone!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES GIBSON
dialogues.text: Has it come to this, though, George? You were talking about the fact we've all become experts on documents in the last few days. Has it come to this, that, that questions get raised? Dan drinks his coffee. Ready for the fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan sits at the anchor desk, delivering the night's broad

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Those raising questions about the documents have focused on something called superscript, a key that automatically types a raised "th."

dialogues.speaker: IN THE FISHBOWL
dialogues.text: Mary and the others watch on monitors. GRAPHICS of the documents with Dan's voice-over:

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Critics claim typewriters didn't have that ability in the 1970s. But some models did. Shots of a 111th from the Killian Memo and a 111th from a official memo are shown side by side.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In fact, other Bush military records already released by the White House itself show the same superscript - here's one from 1968. Some analysts outside CBS say they believe the typeface on these memos is New Times Roman, which they claim was not available in the 1970s. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But the owner of the company that distributes this typing style says it has been available since 1931. Shots of MATLEY looking at the documents and the enlargem of the signatures.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Document and handwriting examiner Marcel Matley analyzed the documents for CBS News. He says he believes they are real, but is concerned about exactly what is being examined by some of the people now questioning the documents, because deterioration occurs each time a document is reproduced. And the documents being analyzed outside of CBS have been photocopied, faxed, scanned and downloaded, and are far removed from the documents CBS started with. Shots of Dan and Matley looking at the documents.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Matley did this interview with us prior to Wednesday's broadcast. He looked at the documents and the signatures of Colonel Jerry Killian, comparing known documents with the Colonel's signature on the newly discovered ones. Cut to Matley, sitting in a chair for the interview.

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL MATLEY
dialogues.text: We look basically at what's called significant or insignificant features to determine whether it's the same person or not. TI have no problem identifying them. I would say based on our available handwriting evidence, yes, this is the same person. VOICE-OVER from Dan:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matley finds the signatures to be some of the most compelling evidence. We talked to him again today by satellite. 74. Dan in the studio, speaking to Matley on a big screen TV.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you surprised from some of the questions that comes from these? We're not, but are you surprised?

dialogues.speaker: MARCEL MATLEY
dialogues.text: I knew going in that this was dynamite one way or the other. And I knew that potentially it could do far more damage to me professionally than benefit me. But we seek the truth. That's what we do. You're supposed to put yourself out, to seek the truth and take what comes from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the broadcast. Dan pushes through the door and Mary and Betsy rise to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Told you I had it in me.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: I'm calling Andrew right now... She steps away, dialing her cell. Dan shakes his

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: No kidding. What did you think?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I think you parked it. Smith runs up, excited.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Bobby Hodges is on the phone. head.  75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan at his desk, Mary on his couch. Each with a phone to their ear. A beat. Mary punches through the call.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: General Hodges, it's Mary Mapes. I have Dan Rather on the line with me-

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why is the Washington Post describing me as your âtrump card" in this? You tell 'em that, Dan?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I did not, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It says a highly placed CBS source referred to me as your trump card-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: General, that was not me and it was not Dan-

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Because I'm not. I've seen all the coverage, and I have to say, I think the memos are fakes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You- Excuse me? Dan looks over at Mary - what the hell?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I do not believe Jerry Killian wrote those memos. Mary is frantically going through her notebook.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Sir, when we spoke on September 6th- I'm sorry, I'm just going through my notes- when we spoke, you said the content of the memos was familiar to you, is that correct?  76.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And that they "reflected Colonel Killian's mindset at the time".

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They do. But I hadn't physically seen them-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What physically about the memos makes you now doubt their authenticity?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jerry's family says he didn't write them. Mary looks like she's about to pop a blood vessel. Dan tr a different tack.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: General, the thrust of our story was about what happened with the President's guard service. Now if, as you say, Colonel Killian really felt this way and the things described in the memos - pressure from higher up to get him in and then to give him breaks is true, we would like to talk to you about that.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm just telling you I now believe the memos are forgeries-

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Forget the memos. Is what we presented regarding President Bush accurate? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don't want to get in the middle of this.  77.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Would you be willing to sit down with me tomorrow? I can come there-

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Maybe after the election.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: General-

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HODGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The family says they're fake and I'm supporting the family. I'm sorry. CLICK. He's hung up. Silence. And then

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thick rugs and leather couches. Mary sits on one. Betsy working the phones, Josh stands over her. Heyward at his desk, Gil Schwartz at his side.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: What are we doing about Hodges recanting?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We say we respect General Hodges and believe him the first time we spoke with him. Betsy hangs up the phone. Weary.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: ABC is reaching out to two of our examiners, Emily Will and Linda James. They say they never authenticated.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Of course they didn't. They couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWARTZ
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Because they're copies! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (off their looks) There's no original ink or paper to test, so one can say with a hundred percent certainty they're real or forgeries. That's why they can attack us. Heyward and Schwartz stare at her.

dialogues.speaker: SCHWARTZ
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ...

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: But on the internet they are certain, Mary, and it's killing us.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Those are lousy wannabe analysts-

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: Then we'll get some lousy analysts of our own! We are losing this war!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Our story was about whether Bush's connections got him into the Guard and covered for him when he missed commitments and every bit of research we found backs that up! The documents were just a small part of that, but they weren't the point of the story-

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what the point was! We need to stop the bleeding-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They do not get to do this!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They do not get to smack us just for asking the question! Silence. Josh looks away. Mary doesn't seem to realize what she's said. Heyward turns away from her.  79.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: I want new analysts backing us by Monday morning. Go. It takes Mary a moment to find the door. Josh stays. Heyw looks at him, questioning.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Andrew... The way this entire thing has been handled... If you'd like my resignation, I understand. Heyward stares at him. Softly:

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: Get out of my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary lies on the bed, staring at her ceiling. Bad headach The lights buzz. Her laptop beeps. She crawls to it. New EMAIL. From Dan Rather. She clicks on it. Don't forget to eat. Mary smiles. Then has an idea. Types in a web address. Right-wing message board. Knows she shouldn't, but doing it anyway. Scrolling throu comments. Most of them focusing on CBS. Keeps scrolling. And then she stops. Pasted into the comments is a PHOTO OF HERSELF. Next to i Here's the bitch. Mary stares at it. A beat. Scrolls down. God, does she look like an evil lefty sneak. Somebody wore out the whole bag of ugly sticks on her. Ugly stick? She fell out of the ugly tree and hit every branch on the way down. Scrolls farther. YUP. She sure looks like a socialist to me. Mapes: feminazi propagandist.  80. Methinks she is also of the "diesel" persuasion. A good many of them are forced to join those ranks because men a them like the plague. I'm picturing Sean Hannity right now sharpening his knife gut this witch. Eyes focused on the last three words floating on the scre Gut this witch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrolstad blinks awake. Looks at the clock. 3:31. Looks beside him. No one there. The sound of a printer working comes from down the hall..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sips cold coffee as the printer clacks back and fort HUGE STACKS OF PRINTOUTS litter the office.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: When did you get in? She turns to see him in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I was worried there'd be cameras at the airport. Didn't want Robert to see that. Wrolstad nods, pretending he's okay with that.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: So what are you doing in here?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Working. Wrolstad looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: You want to go take a walk or-  81.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, I don't want to take a fucking walk, Mark, I want to sit here and do this, okay?

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: Okay. He backs out of the room, leaving her to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrolstad blinks awake again. Mary's standing over him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: It's okay. She sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, it's not. It's like no matter what I say or do, I'm gonna get hit.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: This isn't that.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: When my Dad used to start in on me, I'd think, "I'm not gonna cry, I'm not gonna ask him to stop." I'm not going to give him the satisfaction of seeing how much it hurts. So he'd just go harder. And I'd think, Someday, I am going to fight you. (shakes her head) But I never did. Wrolstad stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: Now. She looks up at him, confused.  82.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have to fight now.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ON TV -- An exhausted Dan, interviewing Bill Glennon, an Typewriter Repairman. One of CBS's new "lousy experts".

dialogues.speaker: BILL GLENNON
dialogues.text: Everything in those documents that people are saying can't be done thirty- two years ago are totally false. Proportional spacing was available, superscripts were available as a custom feature, proportional spacing between lines was available; you could order that any way you like... PULL BACK to reveal we are in

dialogues.speaker: INT. 60 MINUTES
dialogues.text: Mary, cutting the interview, with Smith, Colonel Charles, and the Editor. Josh steps in. Shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Word's come down from Andrew. They want to talk to your source.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What if my source doesn't want to talk to them?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Then you'll convince him. You're good at convincing people to do things, aren't you? Mary's eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I just want you to know how important your support has been through this entire process.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Call your fucking source, Mary. He slams the door behind him. The Colonel turns to Smith.  83.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Now it's bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, on the phone with Nicki Burkett. INTERCUT:

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: You said he wouldn't have to.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Nicki-

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: You said you'd verify the documents and he wouldn't have to do anything else-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (sharply) Well, it didn't work out that way, did it? No response. Mary sighs.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Nicki, I'm tired.

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: Bill did nothing wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No one's saying he did. I just need him to get on the phone with my boss and tell him what he told me. Nicki doesn't respond. Mary plays her last card.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It would mean a lot to Dan. Please? Another beat and then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, Dan, and Betsy on couches. Josh and Mary Murphy sit in chairs. Heyward sits at his desk, leaning on a speaker phone.  84.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: Bill? This is Andrew Heyward, I'm the President of CBS News.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is Dan there?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I'm here, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Heard Hodges turned tail on you. All these guys run from it. You know I got health problems? Heyward glances at the others - "who is this guy?"

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: I had heard that, which is why I don't want to take up too much of your time. I was wondering if you'd fill me in on a few things.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: Well, how you came to be in possession of the documents. You told Mary it was from a man named George Conn?

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She was bugging me so much about it I had to tell her something. On Mary, her face sinking. Heyward shoots her a look.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: So that's not accurate?

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, sir, it is not. Mary curses under her breath.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: Would you mind telling us what really happened?  85.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I got a call in March from a guy who said a woman named Lucy Ramirez wanted to get in contact with me. He told me to call the Houston Holiday Inn between 7 and 10 and ask for a specific room, so I did. This Ramirez woman told me she was supposed to be a go-between, a person to deliver a package of documents to me. Betsy scribbles furiously to get this all down...

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I was supposed to copy the documents inside and then burn the originals, which were also copies, and the envelope. Destroy the DNA evidence of where they come from, you see.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So she says "When are you gonna be in Houston next?" And I tell her we're coming to the Livestock Show in a few weeks - we sell Simmental cattle. The Show is an excellent way to advertise our bull semen. On Betsy's notes - burn papers, livestock show, bull seme

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So the first day at the show, a dark skinned fellah comes up, hands me an envelope, walks away. Inside are those memos. I burned the rest like he said. Done and done.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: And was this the same man who talked to you on the phone?

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No idea. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: And you didn't tell Mary all this before because...  86.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Said I'd keep it quiet. Mary did a good job on this. Don't judge her too harshly.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (hollow) Thanks, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: De nada. Heyward, still reeling.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: Bill, this is, uh- this is pretty amazing stuff. Maybe you'd be willing to sit down and talk about it for us? Help clear the air for everyone?

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don't know. What do you think, Dan?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I think they can't hit us any harder than they already are, Colonel. Go on the record and tell the truth. Be done with it. Silence. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: My office will make the necessary arrangements. Thanks for your time.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Goodbye. CLICK. Call over. Everyone sits there in silence. And then Mary LAUGHS at the absurdity of it all. Can't help i

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: You think this is funny?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You don't? It's The Manchurian Candidate meets Hee Haw!  87.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: We need him on camera as soon as possible. Betsy? Betsy nods as the group rises and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mary, hang back a sec? Mary does. The others leave. Heyward shuts the door behin them and turns back to her. Just the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When you sit with Burkett, there should be a line of questioning about his motives. His political leanings, his views on the President. Why he lied. People are going to cover how we cover this. We need to inoculate ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Thou shalt protect the company...

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: Fuck that, I want Dan to survive this.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why wouldn't he survive this? Heyward looks at her. Doesn't respond. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If Dan feels like this is corporate positioning, he won't do it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: He won't for me. He will for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy sits across the aisle. Dan sits at the window, star out at the clouds. Mary is next to him. Watching him. Trying to decide what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, Betsy and Dan exit the airport terminal to find PROTESTERS and CAMERA CREWS shouting at them. Pandemonium  88.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Jesus! A FOX NEWS REPORTER pushes to the front of the scrum, sti a microphone in Dan's face and breathlessly asks:

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Dan, you broadcast those fake memos! Do you feel duped?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You work for Fox News. Do you? Mary hustles him into a waiting car and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crescent Court Hotel - Dallas, Texas. A lushly appointed hotel. Smith and Colonel Charles stand in front motor-cou Smith eyes the nearby fountain. Familiar.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I think I've been thrown out of this hotel... The Colonel spots Mary and Dan's car approaching.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Here they come. The car enters the hotel grounds and pulls to a halt besi the fountain. Mary, Dan, and Betsy get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Where are the Burketts?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Upstairs getting ready.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Dan? He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We need to ask why he lied to us. (exchanging looks with Betsy) We need to make sure we get that.  89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan, Mary, and Betsy come into the Burkett's room as Bill and Nicki rise to greet him.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Just wanted to come in say and hello before we get going.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: Well, thanks for that, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: These things are fairly easy, we'll just sit and talk a bit. I'm also going to ask about why you misled us, didn't want to take you by surprise with that.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: I expected that, and I'll be happy to set that straight.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Great. Anytime you need to stop, get a drink of water, whatever, let us know. If you'll excuse me, I gotta go get my war-paint on. (smiles) Worst part of this is the make up. Burkett smiles as Dan excuses himself. Off to the side, Nicki stands with Mary and Betsy. Her simple cotton dress no match for the fashionable clothes of the news women.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's going to be fine, Nicki. On Nicki's face. Not buying it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights blaze down. Dan sits across from Burkett. Make up caking on his sweaty face. The interview is into it's second hour. Burkett is visibly tired.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: .--But you told us a different story.  90.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: To protect the people who gave me the documents.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Did they ask you to do this?

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: They had wanted me to burn everything they- yeah, they didn't want people to know they were the source on this.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: This man and this mystery woman.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: That's right. (pause) Can I get some more water?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Of course. A PA hands Burkett water. Mary and Betsy walk over to Dan

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: We need a better bite on this. Maybe instead of "Did they ask you to do that", say "Did they ask you to lie?" Dan looks to Mary, who nods.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Okay. Burkett finishes sipping the water. Dan looks to him.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're going to go back for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: This man and this mystery woman, did they ask you to lie to us?  91.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: They didn't want me to say how I got the documents.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: And that's why you initially misled us? Betsy begins writing something on a card...

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: Yes. She hands the card to Mary - So that's why you lied you u Mary looks at her. Betsy nods, urging "go on"...

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your producer was pushing me to find out where I got the memos from. Mary hands Dan the card who scans it.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: So that's why you lied to us?

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: Yes. And I know it caused some problems. He reaches for the water again. Dan pauses as he takes a several gulps from it. Betsy is writing another card. Why didn't you tell us the truth when you gave us the mem Mary raises an eyebrow at her. Betsy gives her another "g on" look. Mary hands the card to Dan while Burkett breath Dan looks at Mary. Not pleased, but he'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (to Burkett; gently) Whenever you're ready. Burkett nods. Finishes with the water. Nicki takes it fro him, not pleased with how this is going.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You say you knew this would cause problems.  92.

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: I know it did, I didn't know it would.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: So, again, why didn't you just tell us the truth when you gave us the memos? An exhale from Nicki on the sidelines. Not happy with thi

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: I was trying to protect people, Dan. People who were trying to tell the truth about what happened back then. Betsy, writing again - So you decided to lie about where documents came from? Mary shakes her head. Not doing it.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: And you believe these documents are telling the truth?

dialogues.speaker: BURKETT
dialogues.text: I do. Betsy hands it to Dan herself. Dan looks at it. Frowns.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: We have that already.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: I want to make sure we have enough so it'll cut-

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: (sharply) We have it. I'm moving on. Betsy moves back to her chair, chastened. Across the room Nicki Burkett stares at Mary, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After. Mary, Betsy, Smith and Roger sitting silence. Pass a package of potato chips back and forth. Smith exhales.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: He's a good guy, you know.  93.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: You think I enjoyed that? We should cut something for Nightly, get it out immediately. Andrew agrees.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: You guys and Dan always say that, what the hell does it mean? A knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's open! The door opens to reveal Nicki Burkett. Lips pursed and eyes glistening. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How's Bill doing?

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: (softly) Don't you dare ask how Bill is. Bill is sick. He's a sick man. And you don't give a damn about him. You just spent two hours trying to destroy him. You made him crawl on- camera. You made him say, again and again, that he lied and it still wasn't enough for you. You wanted More. You wanted to put the blame on him for all the things you did wrong putting this story together. You want to wrap it all up in a neat package and say "It's all Bill Burkett's fault." Well, it's not, and you know it. And you promised when we came here to do this interview, we would get a fair shake and we got nothing from you but lies. She's so mad she's shaking. Everyone else is too.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Nicki-  94.

dialogues.speaker: NICKI
dialogues.text: You may think I'm some stupid hick who doesn't know a damn thing about a damn thing and you are so smart and such a big shot. But I keep my promises and I don't destroy people to protect myself. I don't destroy people and humiliate them and then pretend I give a goddamn about how they are. To answer your question, Bill is not good. But then, you knew that already. Silence. No one else can summon a word. Nicki turns and leaves them. Betsy crumples up the chips bag and tosses it on the table. Not hungry anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a plane touches down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan walks in, hefting his overnight bag. Andrew Heyward stands waiting for him. Dan sees the look in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late. A knocking at the door. Mary clicks on the light an goes to answer it. Dan, in his trench coat.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: What are the chances you have something alcoholic in there?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Better than average.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan sits on the sofa as Mary pours him a drink from tiny mini-bar bottles.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: How long have we known each other?  95.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, it's that bad? Mary hands him his drink and sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: There is going to be an investigation. CBS is going to appoint an independent panel to look in to how the story was put together. I'm to make an announcement about it tomorrow. (pause) And I'm going to apologize for the story on air.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Andrew asked you to apologize? Dan looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: He did not ask.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's surrender.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Since Burkett changed his story, Andrew says CBS will no longer risk its reputation on this.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He knew. Even before we went down there. He just wanted Burkett on tape...

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I need you to do me a favor. I need you to stop worrying about me.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That's not gonna happen-

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You need to protect yourself now. We all do. He puts his drink down and withdraws a BUSINESS CARD. Lea it on the table. Mary looks at it. It is for a lawyer.  96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sits on her couch. Josh across from her. ON TV - The feed from the EVENING NEWSCAST downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Last week, amid increasing questions about the authenticity of documents used in support of a 60 Minutes Wednesday story about President Bush's time in the Texas Air National Guard, CBS News vowed to re-examine the documents in question, and their source, vigorously. And we promised that we would let the American Public know whatever the outcome- Mary clicks off her TV. Can't watch anymore. She looks at Josh. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry this was your first story here.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: I'm thinking next week we should just have Dan shoot the President. Would cause much less drama. Mary laughs. Josh smiles. A nice moment. Broken by Betsy coming through the door, a strange look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Mary? USA Today wants to know if you put Burkett in touch with the Kerry campaign in exchange for documents?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I know what this is about. Josh, remember when I told you Burkett wanted to give the Kerry campaign advice on the swift boat stuff? Josh just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wanted to do a bullshit check on Burkett after he said he'd talked to (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Howard Dean? You said I could contact the Kerry people to check and then Burkett wanted me to give them his phone number and you said I could, so I did. (pause) Do you remember any of this?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (softly) I must not have made myself clear. You must have misunderstood what I said you could do. Mary looks at him, stricken.

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! What else is going to fucking happen here! Unbelievable!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Betsy-

dialogues.speaker: BETSY
dialogues.text: No, you know what, Mary? Maybe it's best if you just went home. Mary looks from one of them to the other. Josh won't meet her gaze. A beat. She gathers up her things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's heels clack on the marble floor as she heads for t exit. TV's on the wall play the CBS EVENING NEWS. Dan's voice, echoing all around her... DAN (0.S. After extensive additional interviews, I no longer have the confidence in these documents that would allow us to continue vouching for them journalistically. I find we have been misled on the key question of how our source for the documents came into possession of these papers. That, combined with some of the questions that have been raised in public and in the press, leads me to (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: a point where, if I knew then what I know now, I would not have gone ahead with the story as it was aired, and I certainly would not have used the documents in question. She pushes out through the doors into the night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrolstad holds the phone to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: ...-I'm sorry, she's not speaking to reporters at this time. He hangs up and retakes his seat next to Mary. Sitting ac from Smith and Colonel Charles, who opens a file folder.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: CBS has hired the firm of Kirkpatrick and Lockhart Nicholson Graham to conduct the Review Panel. Mary looks at her friends.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You paper trailed them.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: (smiles) Of course.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Over a thousand lawyers, headquartered in Seattle. They specialize in internal investigations. They're the ones Bush brought in to rip apart Worldcom last year.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: The same WorldCom that committed an 11 billion dollar fraud leading to the largest bankruptcy filing in US History?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And we're as bad as them?  99.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: It gets worse. Colonel Charles flips the page.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: The panel will be co-chaired by K and L partner Richard Thornburgh. Mary and Wrolstad can't believe it. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Former governor of Pennsylvania, first appointed as a U.S. Attorney by Richard Nixon. Ran for Congress twice, lost to Democrats both times. Second campaign was run by Karl Rove. But the crown jewel of his resume is serving as U.S. Attorney General from 1988 to 1991 under former President George H.W. Bush.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: The man running this "independent panel" worked for Bush's father.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Jesus. Who goes in first?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Dan, then me, then Lucy, the Colonel, then you. You're the grand finale.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Because they want to have everything they can on you before they put you in that chair. Mary doesn't know what to say. The phone rings again. Wrolstad snatches it up.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, she's not speaking with- (pause; to Mary) It's Heyward.  100.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: If he tries to put someone else on the phone with you, hang up. (off their looks) Corporate policy, he has to have a witness on the line if he's going to fire you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Thanks for the pep talk. (taking the phone) Andrew?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: Mary, we've hired a private detective to go back over everything. I want you to turn over your notes, your emails, everything.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I was thinking, if we could track down the actual typewriter-

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: Stop working on the story. He hangs up. Mary puts the phone back. Looks to the other

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: All work official on the Bush-Guard story has ceased. I can't imagine why. Robert stands by the front window, looking out at the law

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: What are you looking at, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: The big van. Mary moves to the window. A NEWS VAN setting on Mary's la Guys run cable into the street. MEN WITH CAMERAS.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are they friends of yours? Mary watches the reporters for a bit.  101.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...Rather's apology has not quieted conservative bloggers who are now calling for criminal charges. As CBS officially begins it's Review Panel today...

dialogues.speaker: INT. 60 MINUTES
dialogues.text: Mary Murphy looks up as Smith walks past.

dialogues.speaker: MARY MURPHY
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I left my wallet in a cab, I'm supposed to be over at Black Rock for the panel this morning-

dialogues.speaker: MARY MURPHY
dialogues.text: You can't be here.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Excuse me? He sees Josh coming down the hallway towards him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You're not allowed in the building.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I'm not allowed in the building according to who?

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Management. You have to go now. Josh gestures to the door. Smith stares at both of them.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Do you even understand what's happening right now?  102.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (picking up a phone) I understand that you're leaving.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Right now Viacom is lobbying a Republican controlled Congress for deregulation and tax breaks that would save the company hundreds of millions of dollars - and we just aired a report that could cost Republicans the Presidency!

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Security to the 9th floor now please?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: You don't think Viacom needs the Administration on their side? You don't think they're desperate to make it up to them right now? Make up for CBS running stories on Abu Ghraib and the President and Vietnam and all the shit that isn't part of their regularly scheduled programming? Everyone wants this to disappear! (disgusted) There's a fucking election at stake! We're supposed to question everything and you won't even question this! People's heads poke out of their offices at the yelling.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: Are you done?

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: You know when the FCC repealed cross ownership laws a single company was allowed to own forty-five percent of the National Market Share? Forty- five percent. People fucking flipped. They actually wrote their congressmen. So in the 2003 Appropriations Bill, Congress overturned it. Hooray for democracy, right? A crowd has now gathered around this ranting former emplo  Silence. Smith, abo and walk h The doors

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black Rock monolithic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith sits about to b Dan thinks 103.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Except the President wouldn't sign it. Bush threatened to veto the entire bill unless a compromise was found at thirty-nine percent and why? Because at that exact percentage, both Viacom and Newscorp wouldn't have to sell off any stations. The President of the United States was ready to take down the entire federal budget so that Viacom wouldn't lose money! The staffers look to Josh.

dialogues.speaker: JOSH
dialogues.text: You're right. We're all evil and you're the plucky misunderstood hero. It wasn't that you guys fucked up a story - it's the conspiracy, right? ut to retort when TWO LARGE SECURITY GUARDS appear im to the elevator. Smith gets on. Looks at Josh.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: They're gonna screw you too, you know. close between them.

dialogues.speaker: ROCK
dialogues.text: - CBS Corporate Headquarters. Establishing. The black tower at West 52nd and Sixth.

dialogues.speaker: ROCK
dialogues.text: across from Dan and SEVERAL LAWYERS. Like kids e@ called into the Principal's office. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I never asked you why you got into journalism. about it for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Curiosity.  104.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: That's everything. (smiles) Why did you get into it? Smith looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: You. On Dan as this lands. The door opens and LAWYER approache

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: The panel is ready for you, Mr. Rather. Dan smiles at Smith and rises. Walks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sits alone in a booth. Pops a Xanax. Watching a woma in the BAKERY SECTION decorate a cake. Fascinated by it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That's amazing. How do you get the icing to do that, with the piping?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: It's no big thing.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it is. It's beautiful. Interrupted as Smith slides into the booth across from he

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: They asked if you bullied staff or sources. If you tried to physically intimidate people into doing what you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And I hope you told them I regularly beat the shit out of you-

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: This isn't a joke, Mary! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) They asked about your politics. She stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Deck's stacked. Game's rigged. (shakes his head) Between them and talk radio and your father, it's a fucking lynching...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What about my father? Smith blinks. Said something he shouldn't have.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: It's nothing, forget it-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What about my father, Mike? So loud that heads turn. The cake lady frowns.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: (softly) I thought you knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary stands with Wrolstad. A NEWSCAST on TV. Replaying a radio station CALL IN SHOW. Mary Mapes' Father Calls In! Voices from the TV. One of them belongs to DON MAPES.

dialogues.speaker: DON MAPES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm ashamed of what my daughter has become. Mary shakes like a child at the sound of his voice...

dialogues.speaker: RADIO HOST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You are?

dialogues.speaker: DON MAPES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She's a typical liberal. She went into journalism with an axe to grind and that was to promote radical feminism.  106. Like each word is a slap...

dialogues.speaker: RADIO HOST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So this is a pattern of hers?

dialogues.speaker: DON MAPES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. When I heard this was a 60 Minutes story, I figured she would be the producer of the show. She and Dan Rather have been working on this ever since Bush was elected. She should be really be looking at George Soros or Michael Moore- Mary can't take it anymore - she stabs at the television turn it off. Walks from the room without a word. Broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrolstad pulls an address book from a cluttered drawer. Dials the cordless phone. Walks into the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it rings. Pacing tightly. The phone is answered.

dialogues.speaker: DON MAPES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: You can't talk to the press anymore, Don.

dialogues.speaker: DON MAPES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: You know who. For once in your life, be decent. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DON MAPES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm expressing my opinion. I thought you reporters were all about that-

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: Don, if you don't stop talking to the press, I'm going to fly up there and break your fucking arms.  107.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is that him? Wrolstad turns to see Mary standing by the back door. He doesn't know whether to tell her or not.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me talk to him. She extends her hand for the phone. Wrolstad gives it to her. We think she's going to lay into him, but instead:

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (softly) Daddy, please, stop. A beat. An exhale of breath from the other end.

dialogues.speaker: DON MAPES
dialogues.text: Well since you asked, I will. CLICK. He's hung up. Mary swallows. Tosses the phone on the lawn and goes back inside. Done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary lies in what almost looks like a catatonic state. No lights on, just the fading sun coming through the slats i the shutters. Wrolstad steps quietly into the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I can't anymore.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: You can.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don't want to. They can have my career. I don't care. (deep breath) I never should have asked the question... Wrolstad looks at her. He knows that's not true.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: So they're right and you're wrong?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Guess so.  108.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: And Dan? She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That's not fair.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: "It's a shame what that woman did to Dan Rather." That's what they're saying on cable.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (softly) Don't...

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: How's he's going to go down a disgrace. And Robert will get to see you quit, that'll be good for him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Fuck you... He puts his hand on her brow.

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: You have to make your case to the Panel. You have to fight.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Even if the system is rigged?

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: The system is rigged. Always has been. But you still have to tell them what happened. Mary stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why? Wrolstad smiles at his wife - isn't it obvious?

dialogues.speaker: WROLSTAD
dialogues.text: Because that's what we do.  109. And he strokes her brow as she looks at him and then we

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: KNITTING NEEDLES clicking softly together, as they make l of yarn. A clock on the wall ticks. We're back in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sits as she has before. Exhausted. As the Receptioni looks up to tell her that Mr. Hibey will see her now...

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So. Do you believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sits across from the lawyer. Tale told. Hibey blinks

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do you believe I did my job?

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: I told you, it doesn't matter what I believe-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It does to me.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: If you'd like someone else to represent you in this, I understand. He looks to the door. She doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Tell me why I shouldn't. Hibey leans back in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: What do you want out of this?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: Do you want to get into a debate about journalism with them or do you want to keep your job?  110.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I can't do both?

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: Not at this point, no. (pause) You're the primary breadwinner, is that correct?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: And your son is seven? Mary stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This isn't a trial, this is a hunt. This is about assignation of blame - who is at fault, because somebody has to be. Debate that with them and you're done. Mary looks at him. The needles have stopped.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have one chance here. Among all the conservative lawyers on the panel, there is one former journalist. One man who can maybe understand what happened. You convince him... maybe he can turn the rest of them. (pause) But if you antagonize them, if you bait them, if you fight them - you will lose. Mary looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You're hired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary going through her notes with Hibey's assistants.  111.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You're going to cooperate in every way, follow every request and instruction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Hibey exit a taxi in front of the large and impo monolithically black CBS Corporate Headquarters Building.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There is no standard here. No books full of journalistic laws, no written codes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Secretaries crane their necks to catch a glance of Mary a Hibey as they walk past. The walls plastered with posters from CBS shows. Lucy and Desi. MASH. And Dan Rather.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There's just opinion...

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And we have to sway it. Mary and Hibey, taking their seats on one side of the conference table. On the other is THE PANEL. Hibey nods t the older man in the back of the room.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispering to Mary) That's Thornburgh.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Where's the journalist? Hibey points to the bespectacled gentlemen to the side. O of the lawyers in the front speaks.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: Ms. Mapes, thank you for coming in. I'm Larry Lanpher. I'm Lead Council along with Mike Missal here.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE MISSAL
dialogues.text: A pleasure.  112. Hibey looks around the room.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: I notice there's no stenographer.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE MISSAL
dialogues.text: This is an internal investigation. We're just going to take some notes as we go. He nods to two women with notebooks and pens.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: So there will be no official record? Lanpher ignores the question with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: Would you like to take a bathroom break before we begin?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: You're sure? Mary smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm not that delicate.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: I'd like one.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: Okay. Start in ten minutes everyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibey pulls Mary into a small room off the conference roo

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: I need you to stay calm.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don't I look calm?  113.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: Not even a little. They're going to try and catch you off balance. When they ask a question, answer it. Tell them what time it is, don't tell them how to build a clock.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But-

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: Don't fight. He holds her gaze. She nods. They head back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missal slides a stack of papers across the table.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE MISSAL
dialogues.text: I'd like to talk a little about language.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE MISSAL
dialogues.text: These are the printouts of emails sent back and forth by your group during the investigation. Hibey pages through them.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE MISSAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In this one to Mike Smith, what did the two of you mean when you discussed a piece of "tasty brisket"?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That referred to a piece of information Mike uncovered working on a documentary for the Germans.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE MISSAL
dialogues.text: A piece of information against the President.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I think specifically it referred to Bush losing his nerve while flying.  114.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE MISSAL
dialogues.text: Which was not mentioned in the report you aired on 60 Minutes.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I didn't think we had it nailed down.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE MISSAL
dialogues.text: So, is it accurate to say that you were looking for anything negative about the President? Hibey looks over to Mary. Careful here...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I would say it's accurate that we were looking for any information about his time in the Air National Guard that had not yet come to light.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE MISSAL
dialogues.text: And that's why it's "tasty"? Not because it reflected poorly on the President?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It was tasty because it had the potential to be newsworthy. Mike and I are friends, we use a shorthand. Sarcasm, jokes.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: Is that common in your industry?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: When dealing with matters as serious as this, it's common to make jokes?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I can assure you, we take our work very seriously.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE MISSAL
dialogues.text: I also wanted to ask you about this email from Roger Charles where he says he "feels better" about the (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MIKE MISSAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: documents because of their formatting. Colonel Charles originally thought the documents were fake? Mary blinks.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don't believe so.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE MISSAL
dialogues.text: Then why would he say here that he "feels better"?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Because it seemed that what our source was telling us was true.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: I have to disagree. Even the subject line of the email is "I feel better" with three exclamation points. It seems that Colonel Charles initially had doubts.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You would have to ask Colonel Charles. Hibey nods. Good answer. But Mary continues:

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But also, I'd say he was coming from a place of not being sure whether the memos were real or not and then becoming confident that they were.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: Really? (smiles ) You'll forgive me for saying, but your testimony so far doesn't bear that out.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: (sensing danger) This isn't testimony, remember?  116.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: If it was impossible to authenticate the memos, doesn't it stand to reason that you initially assumed that the memos were real rather than the other way around?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I wouldn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: Well, what would you say? Mary stares at him. On Hibey.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It seems to me you assumed these memos were real from the outset, and you looked to make sure that nothing disproved that. Essentially, you took the position that the President was guilty until proven innocent. Shit.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We took several steps to vet these memos .

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: Such as? There's only two signatures, and two sets of initials - hardly enough comparison for a handwriting match. You said yourself no ink or carbon tests could be performed, in fact two of the four analysts you hired have said they had strong reservations about the memos authenticity.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Much of the formatting and terminology used is consistent with the period-

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: That's debatable-  117.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (insisting) Is consistent with the period, as is the content of the memos, which was verified by several different sources who knew Colonel Killian-

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: Then what about this? (reading a memo) "O.E.T.R." Is this one of the terminologies that was "consistent with the period"?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I believe so.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: What's it stand for?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: "Officer Effectiveness Training Report."

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: Actually, the correct acronym is O.E.R. - "Officer Effectiveness Report". No T. (pause) Isn't it true, Mary, that the phrase "Officer Effectiveness Training Report" doesn't actually appear anywhere on any official documents? That this phrase is something you created to explain this incorrect abbreviation in your memos? Hibey stares at Mary, stricken. Checkmate.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That's not true.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: It isn't?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I wouldn't do something like that.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: Then prove it.  118. A beat. All eyes on Mary. She opens up her binder and withdraws a piece of paper. Slides it across the table.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Official document. Top of the page. Lanpher looks. The others around him do too. The top of the page reads - Officer Effectiveness Training Report. A beat. Mary looks at Lanpher, pleasantly. Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: Oh. I see that. Sorry, my mistake. Hibey beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Hibey watch as the panel files out. BOCCARDI, th journalist, smiles at them as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: Clearly you did well. They'll regroup and call you back in next month.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Next month?

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: They've decided to delay announcing the Panel's findings till after the election. Mary stops in her tracks.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't look so glum. Keep your head down and you'll make it out of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrolstad stands on a step ladder, putting up Christmas li Several other houses twinkle. A chill in the air.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT BUSH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I want to thank you all for your hard work in the campaign...  119.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary wrapping a VIDEO CAMERA for Robert for Christmas. ON TV - President Bush doing a PRESS BRIEFING.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT BUSH
dialogues.text: I told you that the other day, and you probably thought I was just seeking votes. But now that you voted, I really meant it. LAUGHTER from the press corps. Over more

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT BUSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I appreciate the hard work of the press corps. We all put in long hours, and you're away from your families for a long period of time. But the country is better off when we have a vigorous and free press covering our elections. Without over-pandering, I'll answer a few questions. Hunt? laughter reporter TERENCE HUNT speaks.

dialogues.speaker: TERENCE HUNT
dialogues.text: Mr. President, thank you. As you look at your second term, how much is the war in Iraq going to cost? Do you intend to send more troops, or bring troops home? And in the Middle East, more broadly, do you agree with Tony Blair that revitalizing the Middle East peace process is the single most pressing political issue facing the world?

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT BUSH
dialogues.text: Now that I've got the will of the people at my back, I'm going to start enforcing the one-question rule. That was three questions. More laughter. They love this guy. The phone rings and Mary mutes the TV to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hello?  120.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan, holding a glass of scotch. Tie loosened, jacket off. The door to his balcony is open.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Mary, it's Dan plus three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm working on a chardonnay Xanax cocktail if it makes you feel any better. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan takes a swallow of scotch and steps out to the balcon

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Did you know that 60 Minutes was the first news program to ever make money? Before that, all news divisions operated at a financial loss. He looks out at the city.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When the government gave networks the airwaves, it was with the stipulation that they would be used in some capacity for the public good. And that was the news. They made their money elsewhere on the schedule. But reporting the news was a duty. A public trust. Mary doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When Hewitt started 60 Minutes in 1968, it built to enormous ratings. It was wonderful. People were really watching news. Caring. And we figured out a way to give it to them. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sips) I was there, Mary. I was there the day they figured out news could make money. The traffic below him is honking. He doesn't seem to noti

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After a while it dawned on them; how come the Evening News isn't a profit center too? Why aren't the morning shows earning more? If you interview Survivor contestants instead of survivors of genocide, your ad rates go up. Pretty soon we won't even run down our own stories cause it's too expensive. We'll just pay someone else to do it, then read them on the air for show. (pause) It was a public trust once. I swear to you it was. Very softly, Mary asks him again.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How are you doing, Dan? Dan drains the rest of the scotch and examines his glass.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: I'm stepping down as anchor. In her kitchen, Mary stands very still.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: After Inauguration.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, Dan...

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: You didn't cause this, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You're a shitty liar, you know that? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (tears in her eyes) Why didn't you ask me? Everyone else asked after the shit hit the fan, why didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Ask you what?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Why didn't you ask me if the documents were real?

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Because I knew I didn't need to. Mary is silent.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When you go back in there, you hold your head up, understand? Mary smiles through the tears.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, Dad. A beat. Dan puts down his glass. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thunder and lightning outside. Late in the day. Dinner break. Mary watches Panel members through the open door.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: You're doing great. Another half hour and we're done. Mary nods, her mind anywhere but here. Like she's decidin something. Doodling absently on a legal pad. "FEA". Hibey looks at the letters on the page.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What does that mean? She looks up at him.  123.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Fuck 'em all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Hibey sit across from the panel. One more time. Rain streaks the windows. Things are wrapping up.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE MISSAL
dialogues.text: ...-Well, I'm glad we have clarification on that.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: Good. If there's nothing else? Missal and the others move to rise. Mary keeps her seat.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to ask about my politics? Missal blinks. Hibey shoots her a warning look.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You've asked other people what I believe. Aren't you going to ask me?

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: (hissing to Mary) What are you doing? The journalist, LOU BOCCARDI, finally speaks.

dialogues.speaker: LOU BOCCARDI
dialogues.text: Well, wouldn't you say most people you work with think you're a liberal?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do you mean, "Am I now, or have I ever been a liberal"? A number of the panel shifts in their seats uncomfortably

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: It's a legitimate question.  124.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE MISSAL
dialogues.text: You brought it up.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, you did when you asked all my co- workers. So I'll tell you. I don't believe in labels. I think most people have a mixture of views-

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: That's not what we're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Then what are you talking about, Larry?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: We're talking about you bringing your politics into your reporting.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I did nothing of the kind.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY LANPHER
dialogues.text: Really? Nothing? Is that why when Barnes said he got Bush into the Guard, you believed him without question?
