That when Bill Burkett, an outspoken Bush critic and admitted liar brought you memos, you assumed their authenticity and didn't bother to source them? That when not one but two of your four document examiners expressed doubts the memos were real, you pushed them aside and rushed the story on air? And why you personally contacted John Kerry's campaign on behalf of a man who had dedicated himself to smearing the President? (staring at her) Tell me, Mary, where exactly does politics not enter into any of this? Or are you just that bad at your job? A beat. Lanpher's breathing hard. The others stare at him  Silence. 125.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Do you know what it would take to fake these memos?

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: Mary-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, this is important. It would require the forger to have an in depth knowledge of the 1971 Air Force manual, including rules, regulations, and abbreviations. He would have to know Bush's official record backwards and forwards to make sure that none of these memos conflicted with it. He would have to know all the players in the Texas Air National Guard at the time - not just their names but their attitudes and opinions including how they related to one another. He would have to know that Colonel Killian kept personal memos for himself like this in the first place. He would have to know how Killian felt at the time, particularly about his superiors and then first Lieutenant Bush. He would have to know or learn all of this in order to fool us as you assume he did. (leaning forward) Now. Do you really think a man who takes that kind of time and precision then goes and types these up on Microsoft Word? The men stare at her. Nobody has a response to that. Thunder in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Our story was about whether Bush fulfilled his service. But nobody wants to talk about that. They want to talk about fonts and forgery and conspiracy theories. Because that's what people do if they don't like a story these days. They point and scream. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They question your politics, your objectivity - hell, your basic humanity - and then they hope to God the truth gets lost in the scrum. (shaking her head) And when it's finally over, they've kicked and shouted so loud we don't even remember what the point was. Rain continues to fall. And then from the back of the roo

dialogues.speaker: DICK THORNBURGH
dialogues.text: But you didn't prove it. They all turn to him. The old man finally speaks.

dialogues.speaker: DICK THORNBURGH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You didn't prove Ben Barnes got the President into the Guard. You didn't prove the memos are real. The burden of proof is on you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: By that standard the Times would never have run the Pentagon Papers, the Post would never have listened to Deep Throat-

dialogues.speaker: DICK THORNBURGH
dialogues.text: Ben Barnes is hardly Deep Throat-

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ben Barnes has confessed to abusing his power to keep some of the richest and most privileged sons of Texas from getting their asses blown up in Vietnam!

dialogues.speaker: DICK THORNBURGH
dialogues.text: Ms. Mapes, don't you think that it's possible, just possible, that some of those fine young men got into the National Guard on their own merit? Mary blinks. A beat. And then she answers truthfully.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, sir. No, I do not.  127. Thornburgh nods. A beat. He's heard what he came to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has grown to a downpour. Mary and Hibey step out the door. Pausing at the edge of the deluge.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: Had to do it, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: In the immortal words of Popeye - "I am what I am".

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY
dialogues.text: I would've gone with "To thine own self be true" but Popeye works. (pause) They'1l have their findings in a few weeks. I'll call you when I hear. She extends a hand. They shake. Then she turns, heading off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, Mary? Mary turns back. Standing there in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: HIBEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sits with Robert, playing with his video camera. The phone in the other room rings. Mary gets up to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mary, the report is out and it's very bad. I'm going to put Jonathan Anschultz on the line. Mary's shoulders slump.  128.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jon, can you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW HEYWARD
dialogues.text: Mary, as I said, the report is bad. You're being terminated. Mary closes her eyes as Heyward keeps speaking. She's not even listening. As we begin cutting around to see the oth losing their jobs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy at her desk. She throws the phone across the room..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Murphy crying as she is being let go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half of the office in boxes. Josh carefully taking down t row of Emmys from the shelf behind his desk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, returning to her classroom to find her students wai smiling. They've strung up a banner that says "SO, YOU GO FIRED." Lucy laughs as they rise and applaud her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike Smith, carrying his box of stuff down the stairs and out the front door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith carrying a box of stuff to his truck. Someone stand next to it. Waiting. Colonel Charles. Smith smiles.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: Hippie scum.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: Jarhead fuck. Colonel Charles offers his hand.  129.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: You ever need a reference...

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: I can tell them how we destroyed modern journalism together? The Colonel laughs. They shake.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL CHARLES
dialogues.text: I'll see you. He turns and walks off into the dying sun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sundown. Mary and Wrolstad sit on their couch. Wine uncor on the table. And the CBS Evening News on TV.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: We have shared a lot in the 24 years we've been meeting here each evening. And before I say good night, this night, I need to say thank you. Wrolstad takes Mary's hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds have turned out to watch Dan's final broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: DAN
dialogues.text: Thank you to the thousands of wonderful professionals at CBS News, past and present, with whom it has been my honor to work, over these years. And a deeply-felt thanks to all of you who have let us into your homes, night after night. It has been a privilege, and one never taken lightly. INTERCUT with Mary and Wrolstad watching...

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To a nation still nursing a broken heart for what happened here in 2001 and especially those who found themselves closest to the events of (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: September 11th. To our soldiers, sailors, airmen, and Marines in dangerous places. To those who have endured the tsunami and to all who have suffered natural disasters and who must find the will to rebuild. To the oppressed and to those whose lot it is to struggle, in financial hardship or in failing health, to my fellow journalists in places where reporting the truth means risking all, and to each of you... (smiles) Courage. Mary takes a breath. Tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For the CBS Evening News, Dan Rather reporting. Goodnight. The screen fades to black.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STUDIO
dialogues.text: Dan rises to thunderous applause. Smiling at the people there. A little teary eyed himself. Champagne is popped. Among those clapping, Heyward. Dan catches his eye. Heywa smiles. Dan turns away from him and begins a conversation Heyward's smile falters just a bit. But he keeps applaudi Dan turns and walks away from camera. Leaving us. Leaving the stage. As he goes, these words appear: The Independent Panel Report found no political bias in t reporting of the Guard Story. Josh Howard, Mary Murphy, a Betsy West were asked to resign. Mary Mapes was fired. 10 days later, President George W. Bush was inaugurated f a Second Term. These words fade. Replaced by:  131. Dan Rather left CBS and sued, claiming the network caved political pressure to placate the White House. The suit w dismissed by the New York Court of Appeals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As commercials and "coming up next" ads play on the television, Mary stares at the image. Then slowly picks u the remote and clicks it off. Silence save for crickets. Mary takes another tissue and blows her nose. Laughing at the amount of tears. Looks to her husband.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You want to take a walk? Wrolstad grins and bounds to his feet. He takes her hand and leads her out the door. And we get the feeling that maybe, just maybe, they'll be okay. We hold on the door and slowly pan back to the television Sitting there, mercifully silent. As we PUSH IN, these words appear on screen... Following Mary Mapes' firing, CBS News won a Peabody Awar for her story on Abu Ghraib. It is considered one of the most important pieces of journalism of the decade. Mary Mapes has not worked in television news since 2004.
